characters: GOT YOU...WE GOT YOU...WE GOT YOU...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blonde, somewhat fragile, intelligent in expression.  She putting on make-up with intense concentration and appreciation, applying lipstick and eye make-up.  As the camera slowly pulls back from the closeup we see that we have been looking into a mirror.  She is standing before full-length mirror in her bedroom doing her make-up.  She overdoes it in the style of the time: rosebud mouth and s forth.  As the film progresses her make-up will be refine until, at the end, there is none. The camera pulls back and continues to move very slowly throughout the first part of this scene.  As the camera continues to move away, we see, by degrees, that BONNIE i naked.  Her nudity is never blatantly revealed to the audience, but implied.  That is, she should be "covered" various ways from the camera's P.O.V., but the audience m be aware of her exposure to CLYDE later in the scene.  Th is the only time in the film that she will ever be this exposed, in all senses of the word, to the audience.  Her attitude and appraisal of herself here are touched with narcissism. The bedroom itself is a second-story bedroom in a lower- class frame house in West Dallas, Texas.  The neighborhoo is low income.  Though the room reveals its shabby surroundings, it also reveals an attempt by BONNIE to fix up.  Small and corny objets d'art are all over the tops o the bureaus, vanity tables, etc. (Little glass figurines porcelain statuettes and the like.) BONNIE finishes admiring herself.  She walks from the mir and moves slowly across the room, the camera moving with her, until she reaches the screened window on the opposit wall.  The shade is up.  There are no curtains.  She look out the window, looking down, and the camera looks down w her. EXT. BEDROOM.  BONNIE'S P.O.V.  DAY. Over her shoulder, we see the driveway leading to the gar connected to the house.  There is an old car parked in th driveway, its windows open.  We see a man walking up the driveway, somewhat furtively.  He is a rather dapper fell dressed in a dark suit with a vest, a white collar, and a straw boater.  It is CLYDE BARROW.  Obviously, he is abou to steal the car.  He looks it over, checking around him make sure no passers-by are coming.  He peers inside the front window to see if the keys are in the ignition.  He studies the dashboard.  BONNIE continues watching, silent Finally she calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, boy!  What you doin' with my mama's car? EXT. DRIVEWAY.  DAY. CLYDE, startled, jumps and looks to see who has caught hi Obviously frightened, he looks up and his face freezes at what he sees. EXT. WINDOW.  CLYDE'S P.O.V.  DAY. We now see what he is looking at: at the open window, revealed from the waist up, is the naked BONNIE.  She loo down, an impudent half-smile on her face.  She doesn't mo or make any attempt to cover herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- whose face changes from astonishment to an answering smile of impudence.  (Seeing what he has, he realizes tha this girl is clearly not going to scream for the police. Already they are in a little game instigated by BONNIE, sizing each other up, competing in a kind of playful arrogance.  Before they speak, they have become coconspirators.) Close-up of BONNIE, still smiling.  Finally she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait there! INT. BEDROOM.  DAY. Running from the window, she flings open a closet and gra a dress, and shoes.  She slips on the shoes, and flings t dress on, running out the door as she does.  The camera tracks with her, moving as fast.  As she runs down the stairs she buttons up the dress. EXT. DRIVEWAY.  DAY. She flies out the door, slamming it behind her, runs off porch (all this has been one continuous movement since sh left the window, in great haste) and continues quickly in the driveway.  Four feet away from CLYDE, she stops on a dime.  They stand there, looking at each other, smiling t same challenge.  For a few seconds, no one speaks, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting her on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't you ashamed?  Tryin' to steal an old lady's automobile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with the same put-on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been thinkin' about buyin' me one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bull.  You ain't got money for dinner, let alone buy no car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still the battle of wits going on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I got enough money for cokes, and since it don't look like you're gonna invite me inside--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd steal the dining room table if I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he moves from his spot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to town with me, then.  How'd that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to walk onto the sidewalk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' to work anyway. EXT. STREET.  MOVING SHOT.  DAY. The camera tracks.  It is a hot Texas afternoon, all whit light and glare.  As they walk the block to town in this scene, their manner of mutual impudence is still pervadin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' to work, huh?  What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretending to give it serious thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you're a...movie star! (thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...A lady mechanic?...No...A maid?--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (really offended by that)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (right on the nose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly startled by his accuracy, anxious to get back now that he is temporarily one-up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What line of work are you in?  When you're not stealin' cars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mysteriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, I'm lookin' for suitable employment right at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly, knowing its effect)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in State Prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State Prison? (she shows her surprise)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (herself again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess some little old lady wasn't so nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tough)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was armed robbery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, my, the things that turn up in the driveway these days. They reach the corner and turn.  They are on: EXT. MAIN STREET.  DAY. --a small-town street of barber shops, cafes, groceries, At the moment, it is deserted.  They continue walking dow the empty street.  CLYDE looks the place over.  Tracking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do y'all do for a good time around here, listen to the grass grow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess you had a lot more fun up at State Prison, huh? CLYDE laughs, enjoying her repartee.  They continue walki At a hydrant, CLYDE stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing off, but seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See this foot? (pointing at his right foot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I chopped two toes off of it.  With an axe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To get off the damn work detail, that's why. (stopping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a lady of some sensitivity)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!... (turning a cute)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I surely don't intend to stand here and look at your dirty feet in the middle of Main Street. They continue walking in silence past a few stores, each planning what next to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, did you really do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gas station up the block.  BONNIE and CLYDE are seen lean against the soft drink chest, their profiles silhouetted the bright sun.  They are drinking cokes.  As they begin talk, the camera moves in closer to them.  CLYDE takes of his hat and rubs the cold coke bottle across his forehead BONNIE watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very interested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, armed robbery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he thinks it a silly question)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's...I don't know...it isn't like anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking she's heard proof that he's a liar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah!  I knew you never robbed bo place, you faker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (challenged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? (studies her, then makes up his mind to show her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close-up.  Gun.  Day.  He reaches in his jacket and pulls out a gun.  The camera moves to a closeup of the gun, glinting in the sunlight. EXT. STREET.  DAY. The camera pulls back to show BONNIE looking at it with fascination.  The weapon has an immediate effect on her. She touches it in a manner almost sexual, full of repress excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (goading him on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well you got one all right, I guess...but you wouldn't have the gumption to use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up the challenge, proving himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just keep your eyes open. EXT. LITTLE GROCERY STORE ACROSS THE STREET.  DAY. The camera remains just behind BONNIE's shoulder so that throughout the following scene we have BONNIE in the pict looking at what we look at. CLYDE goes into the little store.  We remain outside with BONNIE watching.  For a minute nothing happens.  We can barely see what is going on in the store.  Then CLYDE com out, walking slowly.  In one hand he holds the gun, in th other a fistful of money.  He gets halfway, to BONNIE and smiles broadly at her, a smile of charm and personality. She smiles back.  The moment is intense, as if a spark ha jumped from one to the other.  Their relationship, which began the minute BONNIE spotted him in the driveway, has really begun.  CLYDE has shown his stuff and BONNIE is "turned on." Suddenly the old man who runs the grocery store comes running out into the street, completely dumbfounded.  He stands there and says nothing, yet his mouth moves in sil protest.  CLYDE points the gun above him and fires.  It i the first loud noise in the film thus far and it should b shock.  The old man, terrified, runs back into the store fast as he can, CLYDE quickly grabs BONNIE's hand.  The camera swings with them as they turn and begin to run dow the street.  A few yards and the stores disappear entirel The landscape turns into that arid, flat and unrelieved western plain that begins where the town ends. EXT. STORE.  AT THE EDGE OF TOWN.  DAY. A car is parked at the back of the store.  As soon as the reach it, CLYDE motions and BONNIE gets in.  CLYDE runs t the front, lifts up the hood and crosses the wires to mak it start.  As he stands back, BONNIE calls to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's your name, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he slams the hood)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde Barrow. He runs over to the door, opens it, shoves her over, and starts up the engine.  The entire sequence is played at a incredible rapid pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud, to make herself heard over the gunning motor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Bonnie Parker.  Please to meet you. EXT. ROAD.  DAY. VROOM!  The car zooms off down the road, doing 90.  The f country breakdown music starts up on the sound track, goi just as fast as the car. EXT. CAR.  DAY. The car, still speeding, further down the road.  We zoom down and look in the rear window.  CLYDE is driving, we s from behind.  BONNIE is all over him, biting his ear, ruffling his hair, running her hands all over him--in sho making passionate love to him while he drives.  The thril of the robbery and the escape has turned her on sexually. EXT. CAR.  ANOTHER ANGLE.  DAY. The camera pulls back and above the car.  The car starts go crazy in a comical fashion, manifesting to the audienc just what is happening to the driver controlling it.  The car swerves all over the road.  The car comes to a sudden halt.  The car starts again.  It swerves this time almost right off the road before it straightens out.  It jumps a jerks.  Another car comes down the road the other way and CLYDE's car swerves so much as to make the other guy driv right off the road into the dirt.  It is almost Mack Senn stuff, but not quite that much. INT. CAR.  BONNIE AND CLYDE.  DAY. BONNIE grabs the wheel and turns it sharply. EXT. CAR.  DAY. It hairpins off the road onto a shoulder beneath some tre INT. CAR.  BONNIE AND CLYDE.  DAY. --still settling to a stop.  BONNIE and CLYDE appear to b necking heavily now, punctuated by BONNIE's squeals of passion as she squirms and hops about like a flea, trying get to CLYDE.  The floor gear-shift is keeping their bodi apart, however.  In exasperation, BONNIE takes the gear shift and shoves it forward out of their way.  She plunge onto CLYDE, burying him from view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kissing, biting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You ready?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled, laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hey, wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giggling herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you ready?  Well, get ready! BONNIE has obviously touched him.  With savage coquetry s tears into her clothes and his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, honey, c'mon, boy...let's go...let's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey...hey, wait a minute...quit that now, cut it out. (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, cut it out! He shoves her rudely away, slamming her into the far car door.  Suddenly it looks as if they've been fighting.  Bo unbuttoned and unglued, they stare silently at one anothe breathing heavily.  CLYDE gets out of the car, clearly shaken.  Despite the fact that he may have encountered th situation many times before, it's one that no twenty-one- year-old boy in 1932 is sophisticated enough to dismiss easily with bravado. BONNIE remains seated in the car.  She seems terribly vulnerable.  She fumbles about for a cigarette, too confu to figure out what didn't happen.  CLYDE turns back and reaches through the car window from the driver's side, lighting it for her.  BONNIE casts CLYDE a fishy stare, t accepts the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be casual, even insouciant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't do that.  It's not that I can't-- (his voice cracks, the match burns his fingers, and he bangs his head onto roof of car, and he goes right on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --it's just that I don't see no percentage in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean there's nothin' wrong with me, I don't like boys. BONNIE doesn't know what she thinks, and CLYDE is trying gauge her reaction--whether she feels rejected or repelle In fact, it's both--along with a little latent fascinatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally, spitting out smoke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy...boy...boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your advertising is dandy.  Folks'd just never guess you don't have a thing to sell. (a little afraid)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better take me home, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting back into car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch me! She gets out of car, leaving CLYDE draped across the fron seat, reaching after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If all you want's stud service, then get on back to West Dallas and stay there the rest of your life! This stops her.  Now CLYDE pours it on, with an almost maniacal exuberance that becomes more controlled as he ge control of BONNIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're worth more'n that, a lot more, and you know it, and that's why you come along with me.  You could find a lover boy on every corner in town and it doesn't make a damn to them whether you're waiting on tables or picking cotton, so long as you cooperate. But it does make a damn to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning, intrigued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Because you're different! You're like me and you want different things. BONNIE is hooked now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and me travelin' together, we could cut clean acrost this state, and Kansas, too, and maybe dip into Oklahoma, and Missouri or whatnot, and catch ourselves highpockets and a highheeled ol' time.  We can be somethin' we could never be alone. I'll show you...when we walk into the Adolphus Hotel in San Antone', you wearin' a silk dress, they'll be waitin' on you and believe me, sugar, they're gonna know your last name. He stops, having begun to woo her to something more inten than a casual, physical coupling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When'd you figure that all out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time I saw you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intensely, with real honesty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause you may be the best damn girl in Texas. Close-up.  BONNIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BONNIE and CLYDE seated in booth, now C.U. CLYDE.  The so track bridges the scene: the question that BONNIE has jus asked is now suddenly rebutted by CLYDE, as he points a finger at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not answering her, preferring to lead the conversation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you about you. He loves doing this and he does it well.  The more he envisions BONNIE's life, the more instinctively accurate becomes.  She grows more and more fascinated, like a chil watching a mind reader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lessee...You were born somewheres around East Texas...got a big old family, right?...You went to school, of course, but you didn't take to it much 'cause you was a lot smarter than everybody else anyway.  So you just quit.  Now... (thinking, playing it for all it's worth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...When you were sixteen...no, seventeen, there was a guy who worked in...uh... Pull back taking in BONNIE, favoring CLYDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fascinated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cement plant--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  Cement plant.  And you liked him 'cause he thought you was just as nice as you could be.  You almost married that guy, but then...you thought, no, you didn't think you would.  So you got your job in the cafe... (getting closer to home now, hitting them right in there)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And every morning you wake up and you hate it.  You just hate it. And you get down there and you put on your white uniform--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthralled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the truck drivers come in to eat greasy burgers and they kid you and you kid them back, but they're stupid and dumb, boys with big tattoos all over 'em, and you don't like it...And they ask you for dates and sometimes you go...but you mostly don't, and all they ever try is to get into your pants whether you want to or not...and you go home and sit in your room and think, when and how will I ever get away from this?...And now you know. BONNIE is half-mesmerized by his talk.  A waitress comes with their food.  A cheap, gaudy dame, she has spit curls each temple in the style of the times.  CLYDE looks at he and at BONNIE, who also wears spit curls.  As soon as the waitress leaves:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at her hair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change that.  I don't like it. Without a word of protest, BONNIE immediately reaches in bag and takes out a mirror.  She holds it up and with the other hand, brushes back her spit curls into her hair.  S never again wears them.  When she has pushed them back sh looks at CLYDE for his approval.  He nods his okay.  She smiles, puts back her mirror and begins to eat her food. She's ravenously hungry and eats with total concentration her plate.  CLYDE doesn't touch his food, just watches BONNIE eat for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you're a knockout. EXT. ROADSIDE CAFE.  DAY FOR DUSK. CLYDE and BONNIE emerge from the cafe into the early even They move toward the car they have stolen.  Just beyond s a newer model car.  BONNIE is surprised to see CLYDE head toward the newer car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that ain't ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we came in this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mean we have to go home in it. She walks amazed around the new car and gets in beside hi He turns the key and they pull away from the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM. DAY.
dialogues.text: The room is bare.  In the middle BONNIE is waking, having slept on a couple of car seats covered with an old piece tattered blanket.  There are windows behind her.  She loo about bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde... She starts to panic and runs to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde... At another window CLYDE appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chagrined at her fear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you been keeping yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slept out by the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...These accommodations ain't particularly deluxe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...If they're after us, I want the first shot.  Come on, you got some work to do. BONNIE moves to the door and out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the door is a sign which reads:

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTED.
dialogues.text: Wide angle.  Across fence.  Day.  On the dilapidated pick fence six old bottles have been placed.  As BONNIE joins CLYDE he turns and fires six quick shots.  The bottles disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And modest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.  Got you all set up over here. Wider angle.  They move around to the side of the buildin where CLYDE points to a tire hanging by a rope from a tre He means that to be BONNIE's target.  He hands her a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set her spinnin'. BONNIE fires.  She misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again.  Come down slow with it... BONNIE fires again and hits the tire.  She smiles and blo the smoke from the barrel in pride and self-mockery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't you something?  I tell you I'm going to get you a Smith and Wesson, it'll be easier in your hand.  Now try it again once... BONNIE sights.  As she is about to fire, a man appears around the corner of the building.  A FARMER.  She fires hits the tire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heighdo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE whirls at the sound.  He grabs gun from BONNIE beca his is empty.  He aims at FARMER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir...no sir.  You all go right ahead. CLYDE watches him warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to be my place.  Not any more. Bank took it. CLYDE and BONNIE start to move toward the farmer.  All th move around to the front of the building.  At a distance see an Okie car loaded with belongings.  A WOMAN with a B in arms sits in front.  A smaller BOY stands outside the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir, moved us off.  Now it belongs to them. (He points at the foreclosure sign.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's a pitiful shame. CLYDE shakes his head sympathetically.  He loads the empt gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're damned right, ma'm. He looks up to see an OLD NEGRO who has come from a dista shack and now stands near CLYDE's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding toward Negro)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and him put in the years here. Yessir.  So you all go right ahead. We just come by for a last look. He stands a moment looking at the house and then turns around toward his family in the car.  CLYDE and BONNIE lo after him.  CLYDE spins and fires three fast shots into t fore-closure sign.  The FARMER stops and turns, looking a CLYDE.  CLYDE offers the gun to the farmer.  He looks at then accepts it.  He slowly takes aim at the sign and fir It pleases him.  He looks at CLYDE and BONNIE who smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all mind? BONNIE and CLYDE are puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Davis!  Come on over here. The NEGRO moves toward them.  Now BONNIE understands.  Sh takes the second gun from CLYDE and hands it to DAVIS. DAVIS looks from BONNIE to the FARMER and toward the hous The FARMER fires again.  This time at a window.  He nods DAVIS.  DAVIS slowly raises the gun and fires at another window.  It shatters and they can't keep from laughing. FARMER returns the gun as does DAVIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much obliged. He extends his hand.  CLYDE shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis Harrison.  And this here's Davis.  We worked this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (formally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bonnie Parker.  And I'm Clyde Barrow. Across farmer's car.  Wide shot.  Day.  The FARMER turns moves toward his people.  DAVIS moves toward his shack. CLYDE and BONNIE in the b.g. Close angle.  BONNIE and CLYDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We rob banks. BONNIE turns quickly to look at CLYDE.  He smiles and nod

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car is driving down it.  It is the next day.  BONNIE is driving, CLYDE beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just stay in the car and watch and be ready. (he is playing it cool, knowing she is scared.  He thinks he's James Cagney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay now? (he hands her a gun from the glove compartment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just be ready if I need you. BONNIE's hands are tense on the wheel.  Her face shows ho nervous she is now that the time has come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They drive in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you thinkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'. EXT. BUSINESS STREET OF A LITTLE TOWN.  DAY. We are still in the car.  BONNIE pulls over and stops by bank.  CLYDE is frozen in his seat.  We can see that, for all his talk, he is scared, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you waitin' for? That gets him.  CLYDE throws the door open and jumps, practically dives out the door.  The camera follows his motion right inside the bank, tracking very fast. INT. BANK #1.  DAY. Something is very screwy here.  The bank is dark, the TEL is half asleep over his books.  CLYDE approaches, thrusts the gun at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a swagger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a stickup.  Just take it easy and nothin' will happen to you. Gimme the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up with no fear, his voice calm and conversational)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heighdy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonplussed at this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What money?  There ain't no money here, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (totally befuddled at the turn of events)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean there ain't no money?  This here is a bank, ain't it? The camera pans around the bank.  We see that it is empty dusty and shuttered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was a bank.  We failed three weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  What?? In a rage, he goes behind the partition, grabs the teller and pushes him ahead with the gun.  CLYDE is fuming.  He forces the teller out the front door. EXT. BANK #1.  DAY. --showing BONNIE in the car.  She is terrified as she see CLYDE and the TELLER coming at her.  She doesn't understa what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoving the teller forward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her!  Tell her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acting like a man who has had his sleep interrupted by lunatics)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I was tellin' this gentleman, our bank failed last month and ain't no money in it.  I sure am sorry. BONNIE's reaction is one of hysterical relief and appreciation of what's funny in the situation.  She laugh uproariously, she can't stop laughing.  This makes CLYDE madder than ever.  He shoves the teller to the ground. INT. CAR.  DAY. Completely humiliated, CLYDE gets in the car, shoving BON over.  She is still laughing.  BONNIE starts the car.  CL points his gun out the window. Close shot.  Bank window--whereon is lettered: ASSETS-$70 INT. CAR.  CLYDE AND BONNIE.  DAY. Angle to include bank window.  CLYDE aims and puts a bull through each of the zeros.  We see each zero shot through Then the entire window hangs there for a second and sudde crashes.  On the soundtrack, BONNIE's laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --still driving.  BONNIE has still not fully recovered fr her mirth, but is quieting down because she sees that CLY is really mad and can't be pushed too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got $1.98 and you're laughin'. She tries to stop. EXT. STREET.  DAY. The car pulls down another street of shops in another lit hick town.  A grocery store ahead. INT. CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an old CLERK behind the counter, and standing in the b.g., almost out of our vision, is a BUTCHER--an enor giant of a man.  CLYDE steps up to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a loaf of bread, a dozen eggs and a quart of milk. The CLERK gets the order and puts it in a bag.  He rings open the cash register preparatory to asking CLYDE for th money.  CLYDE pulls his gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a stickup.  I'll take all the money in that drawer now. He reaches over the counter into the cash drawer and grab the bills.  He smiles.  Suddenly looming beside CLYDE is BUTCHER, brandishing a meat cleaver.  Camera looks up at this formidable sight as the cleaver comes crashing down, missing CLYDE and sticking in the wooden counter.  He gra CLYDE around the chest in a bear hug and actually lifts h off the ground.  The struggle is in silence.  CLYDE is terrified, fighting wildly to get free.  The gun in CLYDE hand is pinned, because the man has CLYDE's arm pinned to his thigh.  CLYDE tries to raise the barrel at an upward angle to shoot, finally he is able to do so.  He fires. bullet enters the BUTCHER's stomach.  The BUTCHER screams but reacts like a wounded animal, more furious than ever. He still holds CLYDE in a fierce hug, staggering around t store, knocking into shelves and spilling cans.  CLYDE is hysterical with fear.  He shoots the BUTCHER again.  The BUTCHER falls to his knees, but still he doesn't release CLYDE.  In a panic, CLYDE drags the man to the door, tryi to get out. EXT. GROCERY STORE.  DAY. BONNIE sees CLYDE and the BUTCHER holding his legs.  She terrified.  CLYDE drags him out on the street.  The BUTCH won't let go.  CLYDE, in real panic, aims the gun at his head and fires.  Click.  Out of bullets.  In blind fury, pistol-whips the BUTCHER's head with two terrific swipes. Finally the BUTCHER lets go.  Hysterical, CLYDE jumps awa and leaps into the car on the other side.  BONNIE still a the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the hell out of here! They drive-off at top speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE is shaken.  He speaks haltingly, panting; trying to get control of himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn him, that big son of a bitch... He tried to kill me... I ain't got eyes in back of my head... I didn't want to hurt him.  It wasn't a real robbery... Some food and a little bit of dough.  I'm not against him. Damn! EXT. SPEEDING CAR.  DAY. The car is speeding down an open road.  Suddenly it begin to buck and cough.  There is something wrong with the mot CLOSE SHOT.  C.W. MOSS.  EXT. FILLING STATION. His cherubic cheeks are puffed up as he blows into the fu lines of CLYDE's car.  There is a distinctly flat sound. Reaction: CLYDE and BONNIE.  CLYDE stands by the hood. BONNIE remains seated in the car.  CLYDE is covered with sweat and grease--clearly he has gotten in his licks on t engine without success.  Neither he nor BONNIE seems impressed by the noise C.W. is making. Another angle.  C.W.--as he screws back the fuel line and moves between BONNIE and CLYDE to the ignition, turning t engine over.  It purrs beautifully.  CLYDE is astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was wrong, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving back to screw on gas cap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air bubble--clogged the fuel line. C.W. now stands between BONNIE and CLYDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just blowed her away. CLYDE still can't get over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just blowed it away. C.W. belches.  He is embarrassed before BONNIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Scuse me, ma'm... Anythin' else I can do for you? CLYDE nods vigorously, looking across C.W.'s back to BONN BONNIE gets the message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I'm not sure... (she looks around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, them little red things there stickin' up?  Are they gas pumps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he's not too bright)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that interesting?  How does that there gasoline get in my little old car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be helpful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, y'see, there's this tank underground, and the gas comes up this tube into the pump and into your car, M'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, you're a smart fellow.  You sure know a lot about automobiles, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he has no idea he's being toyed with)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, would you know what kind of a car this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's a Chevrolet 8-cylinder coupe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is a stolen Chevrolet 8- cylinder coupe. C.W. jerks his hand off it as if he touched a hot stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting in the conversation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't scared, are you? (to Bonnie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe he is.  What a pity.  We sure coulda used a smart boy who knows such a great deal about automobiles. (suddenly business- like, to C.W.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a good driver, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting quite confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretending to cool on him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so.  He's better off here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.W. Moss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the C.W. for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Miss Bonnie Parker and this is Mr. Clyde Barrow.   We... rob... banks. (C.W. reacts with wide eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swiftly, testing his mettle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't nothing wrong with that, is there, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, nope--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a put-on sigh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he ain't the one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless, Boy, you think you got enough guts for our line of work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affronted in his dumb way)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  I served a year in the reform school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a man with a record!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look here, I know you got the nerve to short-change old ladies who come in for gas, but what I'm askin' you is have you got what it takes to pull bank jobs with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. C.W. Moss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious to prove himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I could.  Sure I could.  I ain't scared, if that's what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prove it. C.W. walks away from the car.  Camera remains where it wa We see him walk inside the gas station office, open the c drawer, close it and come out.  He emerges with a fistful money.  He walks over to BONNIE's window, sticks his hand inside and drops the money on her lap.  We see the bills flutter down.  Not a word is spoken.  BONNIE moves over i the middle.  C.W. opens the door and gets in behind the wheel.  For a moment we see them all sitting there, each smiling their little smile.  CLYDE starts to hum a hillbi tune quietly.  The sound track picks it up (banjo and violin, etc.) and as the music swells, they drive off dow the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room with a bed.  On it, covered by a sheet which humps like a mountain over his enormous stomach, is the BUTCHER.  His head is propped up on a pillow and he sips liquid through a bent glass straw.  Camera is on the left side of the head of the bed, seeing the BUTCHER in a thre quarter profile.  On the opposite side of the bed stands uniformed patrolman who is in the act of flashing mug-sho photos for the BUTCHER to identify his assailant.  The lawman holds a stack of them in front of them, swiftly changing the cards like a grade-school teacher with her flash cards.  At each picture, the BUTCHER grunts negativ and goes on sipping from his glass straw.  One picture, t three go by.  The fourth picture is a mug shot of CLYDE. Again the BUTCHER grunts 'no,' without hesitation.  As th next picture comes into view, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --on a painted wooden sign, lit by one attached light, wh reads: "MOTOR COURT". INT. ROOM IN MOTOR COURT.  NIGHT. --in darkness.  Camera is close on BONNIE.  She is awake restless.  O.S. comes the measured snoring that we will think comes from CLYDE.  BONNIE raises up and kneels over Clyde.  She needs him.  Clyde seems to snore on.  Camera drops between them and we see that the snoring actually comes from C.W.  BONNIE drops back on her pillow.  We cut close on CLYDE.  He is awake. INT. CAFE.  DAY. BONNIE, CLYDE and C.W. seated in a booth in a cafe.  The Waitress brings the food and serves everybody.  We see C. With great concentration, as he does everything by relati to the immediate action he happens to be involved with, h takes the sugar shaker and begins methodically sprinkling sugar over all his food.  He sugars the meat, the beans, the beets.  BONNIE and CLYDE watch this performance with first, amazement and second, disgust.  They can't believe what they see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.W., what are you doing?  Why do you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to eat it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just disgusting, that's why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chewing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to me it ain't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...but it makes everything sweet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. With a resigned expression, BONNIE turns away and begins eat.  Suddenly a look of consternation crosses C.W.'s fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn!  No mayonnaise! He gets up and goes down to the counter on the other end the restaurant, out of our vision, apparently planning to put mayonnaise over the sugar.  The minute he is out of earshot, BONNIE gets CLYDE's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde, why does he have to stay in the same room as us? CLYDE seems not to have heard the question.  He takes up sugar shaker and spreads a thin field of sugar on the dar table surface.  He will sketch his plan in the sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme show you about tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now C.W.'ll be waitin' right outside in the car.  Here is the teller's cage.  Four of them and over here the desks and what have you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Clyde...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the same room with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, where else?  Ain't gonna spread out all over the state... The harshness of his tone concerns him and he recovers wi a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet, anyway.  Now, the door to the bank is here now.  You cover me from there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes his hand to her face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just that I love you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the best damn girl in Texas. C.W. comes back with the mayonnaise; looks at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you spilled the sugar. Three shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The layout for tomorrow up in Mineola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mineola?  Gosh, that's four, five hundred miles from here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?  We take U.S. 85 to Willis Point, don't you know, and cut over on State Highway 28 at Kaufman, keep on goin' till we hit the farm- to-market road that connects to 105 and that's right up by Mineola.  On a Saturday afternoon... EXT. SMALL KANSAS TOWN. The car driving into a small Kansas town.  It is Saturday afternoon, sunny.  The streets are filled with people, ca wagons.  C.W.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is driving, BONNIE is in front with him, CLYDE is in the back.  C.W. looks scared to death at the idea of robbing bank.  The car pulls up in front of the bank, double-park BONNIE and CLYDE get out. EXT. CAR.  DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it running. BONNIE and CLYDE enter bank. INT. BANK #2.  DAY. Cut to the interior of the bank.  BONNIE and CLYDE come i assume the class positions--she at the door where she can cover the bank, CLYDE at the first teller's cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a very quiet voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a stickup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a stickup. This time everyone in the bank hears it.  The people gasp and pull back.  CLYDE slowly edges toward the door and pr BONNIE forward.  She carries a paper sack.  CLYDE motions her to go from cage to cage and get all of the money. BONNIE begins doing so, while CLYDE keeps his gun trained everybody.  We see BONNIE get the money from the first teller, the second teller, then... EXT. SMALL TOWN STREET.  DAY. A car parked in a tight spot has just pulled out. Close-up C.W.  Day--who suddenly looks delighted to see a parking space. EXT. CAR - STREET.  DAY. Immediately he methodically begins to back in.  It's a ti spot and he has to cut the wheel, pull forward, cut some more, pull back and so on.  The scene, for the audience, should be nervous and funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the bank, BONNIE and CLYDE have filled the sack. They run out the door, the camera tracks with them. EXT. SMALL TOWN STREET.  DAY. They run for where the car was, but it isn't there.  Then they see C.W. has parked it. INT. CAR.  DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go!  Let's go! C.W. suddenly realizes what a stupid thing he's done. EXT. CAR.  STREET.  DAY. C.W. tries to shoot out of the parking spot, but he can't He has to go through the business of backing up, cutting wheel and all of it.  The scene is one of pure pandemoniu and chaos. INT. CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on!  Get it out! EXT. CAR.  DAY. A policeman arrives and begins firing at car.  C.W. gets car halfway out of the spot, scraping fenders in the proc and the car is almost out when suddenly a face looms up a the window--a dignified, white-haired, celluloid-collared man, obviously a bank official who has leaped onto the running board.  His screaming can barely by distinguished from all the noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! CLYDE fires through the window. Close-up (special effects).  The face of the man explodes blood.  Then he drops out of sight. EXT. CAR.  DAY. The car shoots off down the road, doing ninety.  Police a firing at the escaping car; BONNIE and CLYDE are shooting out the back window; C.W. is almost having a nervous breakdown at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police car that had been chasing CLYDE and BONNIE's car comes down the street.  It is obvious that the cops have lost them.  They are searching the street for a sign of CLYDE's car.  They pass a movie house whose marquee reads "GOLDDIGGERS OF 1933."  They slow for a moment, decide th is not a probable place to look.  They drive off. INT. MOVIE HOUSE.  WIDE ACROSS AUDIENCE AT SCREEN. The opening musical sequence of "Golddiggers" is on the screen.  Ginger Rogers sings "We're In The Money."  Among the audience we cannot make out our three people.  It is small audience and thinly dispersed. Tight shot at audience.  Camera pans the audience while o the track we hear the music of the song.  First of our gr who becomes visible is C.W.  He is staring at the screen eating bites from a candy bar in each hand.  Camera pans further and we see that CLYDE is in the row behind C.W. a a few seats to one side.  CLYDE is nervous and keeps watc the entrance doors.  He is in a rage.  He shifts in his s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, you gotta be poor in the head. You...!  Count of you I killed a man.  Murder...you too. Shot from behind CLYDE.  Shooting toward screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dumb ass stupid. C.W. turns to CLYDE and nods agreement.  This infuriates CLYDE even more.  He slaps the back of C.W.'s head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever do a dumb thing like that again, I'll kill you boy! Angle at BONNIE.  She has been watching the movie; is now disturbed by the noise.  She turns back to CLYDE from her seat on the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssshh!  If you boys want to talk why don't you go outside? She smiles at her joke and turns back to the screen to th movie which she is obviously enjoying enormously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the right of the screen, f.g., BONNIE stands at the si fixing her make-up in the mirror.  The make-up has become more conservative.  On the left, further back, is a batht and in it sits C.W.  His head and knees peek over the gra soapy water.  He is engaged with his usual single-minded concentration, in washing himself, carefully scrubbing hi arms, not a thought in his head.  BONNIE finishes her mak up and regards herself quizzically, tilting her head to l at herself at different angles.  She is smoking a cigaret and really, studying herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of me, C.W.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...well, you're just fine, I guess.  Uh, well, course you're a real good shot...and...uh...well, sometimes you look pretty as a painting. Camera stays with BONNIE during all this, watching her lo at herself as she listens to C.W.'s evaluation.  She has narcissistic concern at the moment and as she hears him enumerate her values, she thinks about each in turn and decides yes, that's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, uh, Bonnie...could you get me that washrag there? Responding automatically, BONNIE turns and walks to a tow rack, pulls the washcloth off and starts toward C.W. when suddenly she stops with a smile on her face and a sudden motion.  Teasingly, she holds the washcloth out at arm's length.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coyly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'nt you come get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not even realizing what's on her mind)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wiggling the washcloth like a bull-fighter's cape)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whyn't you come get it, C.W.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly C.W. looks mortally embarrassed as he realizes w that would entail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, Bonnie, come on, gimme it. BONNIE tries another tack.  She begins sauntering over slowly, teasingly, still holding out the treasured washcl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pertly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll bring it myself. As she moves closer to the tub, C.W. realizes that she wi be able to peer down into the tub and see him and he frantically reaches up with one hand and yanks the washcl into the tub, causing a great splash.  BONNIE, somewhat t victim of the splash, jumps back and away.  Recovering he composure, she looks at C.W. who is slunk down in the tub like a gross September Morn.  She has tried him and he ha failed; she realizes now that he was no choice for her; n real man, even if he might perform sexually.  He is a lum This irritates her; his very presence is demeaning to herself and CLYDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated with herself for even thinking of such a thing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You simpleton, what would you do if we just pulled out some night while you was asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to give the right answer, but obviously faking it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't know what to do. But you wouldn't do that.  You couldn't now. BONNIE realizes, with some weariness, the inevitable trut of what he's said; thus resigned, she says patronizingly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, C.W.  We'll always be around to take care of you. Pointedly, she throws her cigarette in his bath-water, "Sssssssssss."  She turns and leaves the bathroom, slammi the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera goes with her into the connecting bedroom.  CLYDE sitting on the edge of the bed cleaning the guns and oili them.  He is quiet and preoccupied and takes no note of BONNIE's present condition.  The moment she enters, he lo up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie, I want to talk to you.  Sit down. BONNIE sits, a little taken off balance by his serious manner.  But she listens quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This afternoon we killed a man and we were seen.  Now nobody knows who you are yet, but they're going to be after me and anybody who's runnin' with me.  Now that's murder now and it's gonna get rough. (BONNIE nods.  CLYDE continues speaking carefully and gently.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I can't get out, but right now you still can.  You say the word and I'll put you on the bus to go back to your Mother.  'Cause you mean a lot to me, honey, and I ain't going to make you run with me. So if you want, you say the word. BONNIE, moved by his offer, has tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  We ain't gonna have a minute's peace. BONNIE doesn't like him in this mood.  She tries to josh out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, pshaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to make her see the seriousness of it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie, we could get killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (death has no reality for her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd wanna kill a sweet young thing like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused in spite of himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't no sweet young thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Clyde, I can't picture you with a halo, and if you went to the other place you'd rob the Devil blind, so he'd kick you right back to me. Close-up.  CLYDE--touched deeply, realizes that this was lovely thing to say to him. INT. MOTEL BEDROOM. They kiss.  They are near the bed on which are some guns that CLYDE has been cleaning.  The kiss moves toward real love making.  They are on the bed and push the guns aside Some fall to the floor.  CLYDE breaks the embrace after i has reached a high pitch.  He moves away from the bed tow the window.  BONNIE follows him and embraces him from the rear.  They are miserable.  BONNIE frees him and returns the bed.  She falls on it face down.  A gun presses into face.  CLYDE sits in the window, the light silhouettes hi He turns his face toward the glass and rests his head on window pane.  BONNIE turns to him from bed.  She smiles a comforting smile at him.  She rolls over onto her back. gun is now under her head and moves it.  She sits up and gestures to CLYDE.  He remains at the window.  She stares him.  She looks toward the bathroom.  She looks back at CLYDE.  She is moved and pained for him.  She touches her cheek with the gun and waits for him to be able to look a her.  Finally he does.  Her look eases him and he almost smiles. INT. BUCK'S CAR.  DAY. Shot of little fuzzy doll tied by a white shoestring to t rear-view mirror of a car.  The car is moving; the doll i bouncing up and down.  In the front seat are BUCK and BLANCHE BARROW.  BUCK is a jovial, simple, big-hearted ma A little chubby, given to raucous jokes, knee-slapping an broad reactions.  He is, in many ways, the emotional oppo of his brother.  It doesn't take much to make him happy. BLANCHE, his wife, is the direct opposite of BONNIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is a housefrau, no more and no less, not terribly bright, not very ambitious, cuddly, simpering, madly in l with BUCK and desirous of keeping their lives on the stra and narrow.  As the scene begins we hear and then see BUC driving, singing "The Great Speckled Bird."  BLANCHE is sitting next to him looking at a movie magazine, appearin fairly miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What a beautiful thought I am thinking Concernin' that great speckled bird, Remember his name is recorded on the pages of God's Holy word..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, now you did foolish things as a young man, honey-love, but you went and paid your debt to society and that was right.  But now you just gettin' back in with the criminal element.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Criminal element!  This is my brother, darlin'.  Shoot, he ain't no more criminal than you are, Blanche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that ain't what I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now word of mouth just don't go, darlin', you gotta have the facts. Shoot.  Why he and me growed up together, slept and worked side by side. (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, what a boy he was!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a crook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chidingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you stop bad-mouthin' him, Blanche.  We're just gonna have us a little family visit for a few weeks and then we'll go back to Dallas and I'll get me a job somewheres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just ain't gonna work in your Daddy's church--That's final. (laughing it off, singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What a beautiful thought I am thinking Concernin' that great speckled bird..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUCK's car drives up to the cabin, honking the horn wildl The door of the cabin opens and CLYDE comes running out. is overjoyed to see his brother.  BUCK jumps out of the c equally delighted.  They hug each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hugging him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde!  You son of a bitch! They laugh happily and begin sparring with each other, faking punches and blocking punches--an old childhood rit There is a great feeling of warmth between the two brothe CLYDE is more outgoing than we have ever seen him before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's ma?  How's sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just fine, just fine.  Send their best to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patting Buck's stomach)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you're fillin' out there. Must be that prison food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no! (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's married life.  You know what they say, it's the face powder that gets a man interested, but it's the baking powder that keeps him at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he explodes with laughter and so does Clyde, who loves Buck's jokes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! you gotta meet my wife.  Hey, honey, c'mon out here now and meet my baby brother. Camera swings to car.  We see BLANCHE still sitting there her face obscured by the glint of sun on the windshield. Slowly, she gets out of the car, still carrying the movie magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspiciously, quite the grand lady)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy-do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy-do.  It's real nice to know you. BUCK beams with pleasure, thinking they must like each ot BONNIE comes out of the cabin, standing on the steps.  Th screen door slams behind her. Close-up.  BONNIE.  Day--expressionless, looking it all o EXT. CABIN. BUCK and CLYDE notice nothing of this.  BUCK bounds over BONNIE, all jollity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well!  You must be Bonnie!  Now I hear you been takin' good care of the baby in the family.  Well sis, I'm real glad to meet you! (he hugs her; BONNIE just lets herself be hugged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say... (breaking the hug)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like you to meet my wife, Blanche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. There is an awkward pause.  Suddenly the screen door open and C.W. comes out, dressed in his long underwear.  BLANC can hardly stand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody, this is C.W. Moss. C.W., my brother Buck and his wife, Blanche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (friendly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heighdy, y'all. He pumps BUCK's hand vigorously and then goes to BLANCHE. With his characteristic one-track intensity, he decides t act just as friendly as he can with BLANCHE, ignoring the fact that he's standing there in his underwear.  BLANCHE, however, is not ignoring it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well how do, Mrs. Barrow.  Or can I call you Blanch?  I sure am pleased to meet you. (shaking her hand; Blanche is slowly going crazy with mortification)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have a hard time findin' us here in this neck of the woods? Well, you sure picked a good day for it.  Say, you got a Screenland there!  Any new photos of Myrna Loy? She's my favorite picture star. BLANCHE is starting to edge over to BUCK in sheer panic a this strange, young man in his BVD's but C.W. takes no notice of it. BLANCHE finally grabs BUCK's arm.  BONNIE watches it all, smirking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, lemme get the Kodak! BUCK goes to his car and gets a folding Brownie camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting up a cigar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, C.W., go put your pants on. We're gonna take some pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all hear about the guy who thought Western Union was a cowboy's underwear? BUCK and CLYDE and C.W. laugh heartily.  C.W. goes into t cabin.  BUCK pushes BLANCHE and CLYDE together, posing th for a picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme get one of my bride and my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting kittenish, and overdoing it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck!  Don't take my picture now. I'm just a mess from driving all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh honey, now you look real fine. BONNIE watches BLANCHE's behavior with hardly-veiled disg BUCK snaps the picture as BLANCHE is just about to move o of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with unbecoming girlish outrage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you take my picture?  Oh Buck! I declare-- BUCK laughs and goes to BONNIE, takes her by the arm and moves her next to CLYDE and BLANCHE.  He lines them up, steps back and takes their picture.  CLYDE is the only on smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling out his gun and posing like a movie tough)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Buck, get one of this. BUCK does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving Clyde the camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde, you do one of me and my missus. He puts his arm around BLANCHE.  CLYDE takes the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing her a challenge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take on of Bonnie. BONNIE grins at him and responds with amused arrogance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she yanks the cigar from Clyde's mouth, smokes it and poses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. CLYDE snaps the picture.  Everyone but BLANCHE laughs.  C comes out dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drawing Clyde aside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, brother, let's you and me do a little talkin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing C.W. the camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, C.W., take the girls' picture. INT. CABIN.  DAY. They walk into the cabin.  Camera goes with them.  Bedroo is dark, shades pulled down.  There is an aura of boys' clubhouse secret camaraderie in the following scene:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as soon as the door is shut; conspiratorially)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was you or him, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy you killed.  You had to, didn't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (they are protecting each other)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he put me in a spot, so I had to.  He didn't have a Chinaman's chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you had to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I had to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like two kids keeping a secret from Mom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say nothin' to Blanche about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that time you broke out of jail, she talk you into goin' back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it is obvious he had hoped Clyde hadn't known about it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you hear about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't say nothin' to Bonnie about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...say, what d'ya think of Bonnie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a real peach. There is now a long pause--a lull in the conversation, as they asked each other all the questions and are now out o things to say.  It is too much for BUCK, the natural enem of silence, who suddenly claps his hands together and bur out animatedly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, are we gonna have us a good time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matching his merriment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We surely are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir! (a pause, then:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how's this--I thought we'd all go to Missouri.  They ain't lookin' for me there.  We'll hole up someplace and have us a regular vacation.  All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble, now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble.  I ain't lookin' to go back to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's this I hear about you cuttin' up your toes, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ironically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't but half of it.  I did it so I could get off work detail-- breakin' those damned rocks with a hammer day and night.  Sure enough, next week I got paroled.  I walked out of that god-forsaken jail on crutches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't life grand? EXT. ROAD.  DAY. We see the two cars, one behind the other, driving down a main road. INT. FIRST CAR.  DAY. CLYDE is driving.  BUCK sits next to him.  No one else is the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the doc, he takes him aside, says, "Son, your old mama just gettin' weak and sickly layin' there.  I want you to persuade her to take a little Brandy, y'know, to pick her spirits up." "Why, doc," he says, "you know my mamma is a teetotaler.  She wouldn't touch a drop." "Well, I tell you what," the doc says, "why don't you bring her a fresh quart of milk every day from your farm, 'cept you fix it up so half of it's Brandy and don't let on!" So he does that, doctors it up with Brandy, and his mamma drinks some of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the next day he brings it again and she drinks some more--and she keeps it up every day.  Finally, one week later, he brings her the milk and don't you know she just shallows it all down, and looks at her bag and says, "Son, whatever you do, don't sell that cow!" CLYDE and BUCK explode in laughter. INT. SECOND CAR.  DAY. At the top of the laugh, cut to the int. of the second ca riding right in back of them.  The atmosphere is complete unlike the cozy and jolly scene preceding.  We have dead silence.  BONNIE is driving, smoking a cigarette, grim. BLANCHE--seated as far away as she can get from BONNIE without falling out of the car--makes a face at the cigar smoke, rolls down the window for air.  C.W.'s in the back seat, just staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A residential street in Joplin, Missouri, showing a garag apartment above a double garage.  Camera sees BUCK talkin to a dapper gent with keys in his hand.  BUCK pays him. man tips his hat and walks off.  BUCK gestures and Clyde drives a car into the driveway.  C.W. follows, driving BUCK's car with BLANCHE.  CLYDE stops beside BUCK.  BUCK leans into CLYDE's car and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give him a month's rent in advance.  We're all set.  Let's get inside. CLYDE calls back to C.W. in the following car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull up and unload the stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the running board of moving car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey-love, I'm taking you into our first home. BLANCHE giggles.  The two cars pull up before the garage the people start to descend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A winded BUCK enters and puts down BLANCHE.  As others behind him carry in their things and disperse throughout apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh look, it's so clean, Buck.  And a Frigidaire...not an icebox!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He give me the grocery number. He goes to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme see, eh 4337...Operator... please ma'm, may I have 4337...if you please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...they got linoleum on the counter.  Ain't that clever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Smitty's grocery...I'd like to order a mess of groceries.  Oh yeah...eh 143 Hillsdale Street. Lessee, about 8 pounds of porkchops, 4 pounds of red beans...a can of Chase and Sandborn...uh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, isn't this something, Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sshh.  Uh...quart of milk...uh 8 bottles of Dr. Pepper and that's it, I guess.  No...no.  Uh...a box of Rice Krispies...Bye now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open on BONNIE and CLYDE.  He is cleaning guns.  She is watching something off screen.  We hear a clicking sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, you need a haircut, Daddy.  You look like a hillbilly boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of disgust crosses BONNIE's face.  CLYDE, who has been watching her, smiles.  The clicking sound increases suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha! BLANCHE whoops.  Camera cuts to see that BUCK and C.W. ar playing checkers and BUCK has just beaten him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, you ain't never gonna beat me but you keep tryin' now. He starts to set up the game again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jest like an ol' man.  Plays checkers all the time and doesn't pay any attention to his poor lonely wife. She ruffles his hair again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out now, honey.  I'm gonna teach this boy a lesson he'll never forget. Camera cuts to BONNIE, watching with disgust.  Then slowl a wicked little smile edges across her face.  She watches for a moment more, then she rises and with the most ingen look she can muster up, beckons to CLYDE to follow her in the bedroom.  A little puzzled, CLYDE follows. INT. BEDROOM. BONNIE closes the door and immediately begins fussing wit CLYDE's hair, doing a scathing imitation of BLANCHE.  Tho her miming expresses her irritation at being closeted wit the Barrow menage, it is also a peach doing an imitation a lemon--and it is disarmingly sensual... Indeed the mimi allows BONNIE to be physically freer with CLYDE, and allo CLYDE to respond without anxiety, without self-consciousn We should have the distinct--if momentary--feeling that CLYDE could suddenly make it with BONNIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doing an unmerciful imitation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Daddy, you shore need a haircut. You look just like a little old hillbilly boy, I do declare. (she has her other hand toying with the buttons on his shirt, her hand slipping under, fluttering across his bare chest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh mercy me, oh my stars! CLYDE laughs, and BONNIE tugs at the shirt--she kneels on the bed over CLYDE, who quite easily drapes across it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little louder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Daddy!  Yore such a slowpoke! She's letting her hair fall loose, its golden ends brushi up and down CLYDE's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused, but cautionary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush up a little.  They're in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a mock-pout, but with an edge to it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot, there's always somebody in this room, the next room and ever' other kind of room. CLYDE has his arm around BONNIE, and she's almost draped across him--but in the direction of the length of the bed so their bodies almost form a crooked cross.  She digs an elbow into his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oof!...now that ain't no nice way to talk about my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Blanche again with baby talk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't talking about your brother. Suddenly BONNIE straightens up to a kneeling position aga and cocks her head.  When she speaks now it is with a sim plaintiveness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, do you ever just want to be alone with Me? (sensing Clyde's sensitivity to the sexual implication)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't just mean like that...I mean do you ever have the notion of us bein' out together and alone, like at some fancy ball, or, I don't know, where we walk in all dressed and they announce us and it's fancy and in public, but we're alone somehow.  We're separate from everybody else, and they know it. CLYDE looks up to BONNIE, affectionately.  He runs his ha carelessly down her body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always feel like we're separate from everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it's terribly important to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you, baby? Suddenly there is a ring at the door.  BONNIE and CLYDE freeze. INT. LIVING ROOM. BONNIE and CLYDE run out into the living room, camera goi with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to all)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet!  I'll get it. BONNIE goes down the stairs and reaches the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Groceries, M'am. EXT. GARAGE APARTMENT. She opens the door.  A young man is there with the two bi sacks of groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six dollars and forty-three cents. BONNIE pays him and goes to take the bags from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, M'am, them bags is heavy. Let me carry 'em up for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curtly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, I'll take 'em. She takes the heavy bags and hefts them up and turns and walks up the stairs.  They are obviously very heavy for h Closeup the delivery boy's face, looking puzzled at this behavior.  BONNIE reaches the top steps, and voices are h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
