dialogues.text: What was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet.  Open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, c'mon... Close-up.  The DELIVERY BOY.  A look of suspicion comes across his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close-up of BONNIE--seated in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from a pad; in a recital voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called "The Ballad of Suicide Sal." (she pauses for effect; then begins:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "We each of us have a good alibi For being down here in the 'joint'; But few of them really are justified If you get right down to the point. You've heard of a woman's glory Being spent on a downright cur'."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You write that all by yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to hear this or not? As she reads, the camera pans around the room picking out everyone's reaction.  CLYDE is looking and listening seriously.  BUCK is grinning.  C.W. is blank.  BLANCHE is the kitchen cooking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Still you can't always judge the story As true, being told by her. Now 'Sal' was a gal of rare beauty, Though her features were coarse and tough--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I knew her.  She was cockeyed and had a hare-lip and no teeth! BONNIE flashes him a look that could kill.  He shuts up f She continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Now 'Sal' was a gal of rare beauty, Though her features were coarse and tough; She never once faltered from duty To play on the 'up and up'." Still listening, CLYDE gets up from his chair and walks slowly past the living room windows.  The camera angled slightly above him, sees down the street.  We see two pol cars quietly pulling up.  One of them parks sideways in t driveway to block escape from the garage, the other stays the street.  CLYDE turns and looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. as we see out the window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sal told me this tale on the evening Before she was turned out free, And I'll do my best to relate it Just as she told it to me--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as CLYDE calls out, BLANCHE drops the frying pan the floor and begins screaming.  Camera cuts back to the living room.  Everyone else leaps into action.  Guns begi blazing from everywhere; we rarely see who is shooting at whom. EXT. GARAGE APARTMENT.  DAY. The police, down the stairs into the garage--we follow th with a hand-held camera tracking rapidly. EXT. STREET.  DAY. BLANCHE, however, in utter panic, just runs right out the front door, and begins running down the quiet residential street, going nowhere, anywhere. EXT. GARAGE APARTMENT.  DAY. BUCK, crouching, shooting with one hand, gets the garage door open.  A policeman fires.  BUCK fires back and the c falls dead in the street.  BUCK, firing, dashes to the police car blocking their escape and releases the hand br CLYDE, BONNIE and C.W. leap into their car, gun the motor still shooting madly.  Two more police fall dead or wound One policeman is hurled through a fence by the blast of a sawed-off shotgun.  BUCK jumps into the car with the othe They now begin to bump the police car with their car.  Th police car picks up speed as they push it and it tears in the street right at the group of firing police.  The gang car turns into the street toward the running BLANCHE. BONNIE and CLYDE are in front; BUCK and C.W. in the back seat firing back at police.  The car pulls alongside the wildly running BLANCHE; the back door is flung open and i almost the style of a cartoon, two hands reach out and li her off her feet and pull her into the car.  They speed a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inside of the car, still speeding.  BLANCHE is hyster C.W. is still firing out the window.  The pursuing police car's driver is shot and the car crashes into a tree.  Th gang is not being pursued now, but CLYDE is driving at 90 BLANCHE is moaning and crying.  BONNIE, in front, turns around furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, you almost got us killed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I do wrong?  I s'pose you'd be happier if I got shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at her bitchiest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it would of saved us all a lot of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck, don't let that woman talk to me like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caught in the middle of a bad situation, knowing Blanche is wrong, but trying to soothe her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have done it, Blanche. (quietly, cont.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a dumb thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (switching tactics)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Buck, I didn't marry you to see you shot up!  Please, let's go! Let's get out of here and leave. Make him stop the car and let us out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't.  I killed a man.  We're in this now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud and shrill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please!  Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!  Just shut up your big mouth!  At least do that, will ya, just shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out, Bonnie. BONNIE is affronted.  BLANCHE continues sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curtly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop the car.  I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without a word, CLYDE stops the car. EXT. ROADSIDE.  DAY. BONNIE and CLYDE get out and walk fifteen feet away from car.  Both are irritated and touchy.  Camera follows them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get rid of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't do that.  She's Buck's wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping her words)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get rid of both of them then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  What's the matter with you anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's what's the matter with me, a damn stupid back country hick without a brain in her head. (contemptuously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't nothin' but prunes and proverbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (really pissed-off at Bonnie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you any better?  What makes you so damn special?  You're just a West Dallas waitress who spent half your time pickin' up truck drivers! This hits home with BONNIE.  He has said the unforgivable

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising her voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk to me like that!  Big Clyde Barrow, just the same as your brother, an ignorant uneducated hillbilly. (with deadly archness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only special thing about you is your peculiar ideas about lovemakin'--which is no love makin' at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE stiffens.  The two of them stand silent and tense, almost quivering with anger.  They have stripped each oth raw.  CLYDE turns and looks back at the car.  Everyone is waiting, watching them.  He breathes a deep sigh, like a counting to 10 to hold his temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Bonnie-- He can't finish. Close.  BONNIE.  She drops her head into her hand for a moment, comes up a little more relaxed.  She looks at CLY and her eyes reflect the realization of the pain she has inflicted on him.  She softens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde...honey...I didn't mean all that, honey.  Blame it on all that shootin', I just felt so bad...sure enough...Clyde?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...Okay, hon...let's get movin'... He turns and begins walking back to the car.  BONNIE walk alongside him.  On the few steps back, she regains all he dignity and acts aloof from the others waiting for her. reaches the car.  CLYDE opens her door for her and she ge in like a great lady.  He walks around to his side, gets and they drive off. WIDE SHOT.  EXT. CAR.  DAY. A very wide shot.  We see CLYDE's car driving along a woo road.  For a moment that is all we see, then we should become aware that far in the distance another car is following CLYDE's. Close. Rural mail box.  On the opposite side of the road, CLYDE's car swings across the road and CLYDE, who is driv snatches a newspaper which protrudes from the box and han it into the car.  They drive out of the shot.  Camera hol and soon the following car enters the shot.  The man driv is a Texas ranger.  He drives slowly.  He drives out of t shot. INT. CLYDE'S CAR. BUCK is reading from the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jubilantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, y'all, listen to this here: Law enforcement officers throughout the Southwest are frankly amazed at the way in which will-of-the-wisp bandit Clyde Barrow and his yellow- haired companion, Bonnie Parker, continue to elude their would-be captors.  Since engaging the police in a gun battle on the streets of Joplin Missouri and slaying three of their number...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord... We notice CLYDE is wincing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the Barrow gang has been reported as far West as White City, New Mexico, and as far north as Chicago. They have been credited with robbing the Mesquite Bank in the aforementioned White City, the J.J. Landry Oil Refinery in Arp, Texas, the Sanger City National Bank in Denton, Texas on three different occasions.  In addition to these robberies, the fast travelling Barrows have been rumored to have had a hand in the robbing of two Piggly Wiggly stores in Texas, and one A&P store in Missouri, though Chief Percy Hammond, who first identified Clyde Barrow's brother, Buck, as a member of the gang, expressed some doubt that these last robberies were committed by the Barrow Gang alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde, we ain't goin' to see a restroom for another thirty miles. Why don't you just stop here? CLYDE looks relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls the car to a stop, gets out and goes off into th woods.  We watch him vanish behind the trees. INT. CAR. BUCK still scanning the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey now, here's something!  Listen here: Lone Cop Arrests Two Officers In Hunt For Barrow.  Police Officer Howard Anderson's heart turned faster than his motorcycle when he forced to the side of the road a roaring black V-8 sedan in which were three men and a blondheaded woman yesterday afternoon. Everybody laughs.  As BUCK continues to read, his voice remaining on the soundtrack. EXT. CAR. The camera goes outside the car and pulls back, way back, reveal a police car quietly driving up behind the car.  T car stops a good distance away and one man gets out, the only occupant of the car.  He is tall, dressed in the uniform of the Texas Ranger.  He draws his gun and slowly approaches the car from the rear.  On the soundtrack BUCK voice continues; as we see all this taking place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he saw several machine guns in the car he was certain he'd caught Clyde Barrow, Bonnie Parker, and maybe Buck Barrow and the third unidentified member of the gang. It took a lot of telephoning and explaining to convince the motorcycle cop that his captives were two highway patrolmen and a blonde-haired stenographer from the Highway Patrol--.  Haw!  Haw! (everybody busts up with laughter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meantime, on screen, the lawman is slowly approach the back of the car.  Suddenly, cut to shot of CLYDE comi out of the woods, behind the lawman.  His gun is tucked i his pants.  In a second, he sees what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUCK's voice is continuing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson was held up as an example for every other Texas peace officer today. "That was a mighty brave thing," explained Highway Patrol Chief L.C. Winston. CLYDE whips out his gun.  The following scene is played exactly like a classic fast-draw in an heroic Western.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff! BRYCE spins around.  Both men fire instanteously, but CLY has the draw on him, and the aim.  The gun goes flying fr the SHERIFF's hand.  A really razzle-dazzle display of grandstand marksmanship from Clyde. Immediately the gang leaps from the car and surrounds the man, guns drawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy!  What a shot, Clyde!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet Jesus, I never seen shootin' like that! The gang grabs the man and takes his handcuffs from his b CLYDE makes him lean on the car's hood, arms extended, le spread, while he frisks him.  In general, everyone is excited over the capture.  BONNIE takes the sheriff's gun and delicately places it on the radiator grill like an object d'art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (examining the man's wallet, really surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now, getta load of this.  I want y'all to know we are in the custody of Cap'n Frank Bryce, and Frank here is a Texas Ranger. Rev. angle across hood--so BRYCE's face, not visible to CLYDE or anyone else behind him, is in foreground.  His gnarled, powerful hands tremble slightly on the hood, as they might crinkle the metal like so much tissue paper. eyes stare toward camera relentlessly, unblinking, but without passion.  They are shark's eyes.  They have witne much carnage, devoured it, and are still wide open for mo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure 'nough, Clyde?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say there, peacemaker.  I believe you got your spurs all tangled up. You're in Missouri, you know that? CLYDE has been going thru the man's  credentials.  Not so pleasantly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't know you was in Missouri?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lost, this here Texas Ranger. CLYDE claps BRYCE's hands behind his back, handcuffs him, spins him around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little pissed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --he ain't lost...them banks are offerin' extra reward money fer us, and Frank figured on easy pickin's, didn't you? (he suddenly knocks Bryce's hat off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you? BRYCE flinches involuntarily.  BUCK suddenly grows wary a CLYDE's mood.  CLYDE leans into BRYCE, looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Now you ain't hardly doin' your job, Texas Ranger.  You oughta be home lookin' after the rights of poor folks, not out chasin' after us. He suddenly hefts BRYCE's huge bulk onto the fender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be casual)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy there, Clyde.  Why take is so personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bryce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reg'lar laws is one thing.  But this here bounty hunting, we got to discourage that. BLANCHE looks very uncomfortable.  She starts to say something, but BUCK intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like how, Clyde?-- A tense moment.  CLYDE can't think of anything right away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be helpful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot him. BONNIE shoots C.W. an angry glance--it's just what the ga doesn't want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...hang him?... Reaction--BONNIE carefully gauging the moment to interven

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --uh-uh.  Take his picture. CLYDE's not sure he's heard right.  Neither is C.W.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take his picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointedly ignoring C.W., brightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll let the newspapers have it--so's everyone can see Captain Frank Bryce of the Texas Rangers with the Barrow gang-- (moving demurely to Bryce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and all bein' just as friendly as pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grasping possibilities immediately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...yeah, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing right on, coyly picking up Bryce's gun from grill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --why we 'bout the friendliest folks in the world.  Texas Ranger waves his big ol' gun at us, and we just welcome him like he's one of our own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning widely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck, get the Kodak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved and excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot dog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bryce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're mighty proud to have a Texas Ranger in the family. BRYCE is obviously not pleased with this turn of events. Following dialogue is overlapped, ad-libbed, etc.  A sens of mounting glee at the kind of vengeance they are going exact. New angle.  BUCK is fiddling with the camera, setting up shot with CLYDE.  BUCK's following speech should be heard b.g., to CLYDE's speech below it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...keep him set on the hood, there...more to the sun, like that...yeah...when all his ranger friends see this...I bet he's gonna wish he was dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bryce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...see what come o' your mischief?...not doin' your job? Down in Duncanville last year poor farmers kepts the laws away from us with shot guns...you're s'posed to be protectin' them from us, and they're protectin' us from you. (giggling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --don't make sense, do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, now, Clyde, you and Bonnie first.  Move into him, right close, right friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All righty (to Bryce, whose hands are tied, hemmed in by them both)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move, now, hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE grandly puts an arm on BRYCE's shoulder, BONNIE, looking up admiringly from the other side.  BUCK takes th picture.  BONNIE immediately hops onto the hood, next to BRYCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's this? "Captain Bryce and new found friend." She coyly loosens his tie, tousles his hair, and plants a big kiss on him while still ogling camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...yeah, yeah...quick, Buck, get it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm gettin' it, I'm gettin' it. Quite suddenly BRYCE, whose simmering intensity we should more sensitive to than the gang is, spits on Bonnie.  BON half-screams in disgust, but CLYDE is on top of BRYCE in flash, half-strangling on his own fury.  He pulls BRYCE o the fender by the handcuffs, spinning him around crazily like a lasso.  BRYCE is literally ricocheted off the car the force, and, with CLYDE hanging on by the cuffs, plumm down the embankment to the sandy beach below, both men falling, spinning.  BRYCE rises shakily.  He tries to wal away.  CLYDE grabs him again by the handcuffs and hurls h out into the water.  BRYCE smacks into a tree stump pokin out of the shallows and goes down.  CLYDE is on top of hi Meanwhile, BUCK has rushed down into the water, tries to pull CLYDE off BRYCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the picture.  I got the picture...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oblivious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme be, lemme be... BRYCE reaches the surface and CLYDE tries to throw him in deeper water.  He hitches BRYCE over a moldy skiff, knock aside one of the oars.  BUCK upends BRYCE into the skiff kicks it spinning.  CLYDE picks up an oar and hurls it li a boomerang, ass over end at the skiff.  It kicks up a sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding tightly to Clyde, yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the PICTURE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reaction.  CLYDE waist deep, breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...All right, all right... (to Bryce, yelling)

dialogues.speaker: GOT YOU...WE GOT YOU...WE GOT YOU...
dialogues.text: BRYCE, battered and handcuffed, stares back with mindless malice from the lazily spinning skiff to the hysterical spectre of CLYDE, screaming his madness across the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the bank.  In contrast to the previous inept bank robbery scene, this one goes admirably well, the gang performing slickly and without a hitch.  As they enter, dripping wet, CLYDE makes a general announcement to every to the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Barrow gang. (the people turn and freeze)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody just take it easy and nobody will get hurt. CLYDE covers the door.  BONNIE and BUCK go to the tellers cages and get money.  BUCK goes inside, emptying out the cash drawers.  Cut to BONNIE filling the sack. Cut to a close-up of a burglar alarm button.  Slowly a ha crawls up the wall and a finger slowly moves to push the button.  When the finger is about one inch away, suddenly gun appears in the frame and gently taps the hand away. camera pulls back to reveal BUCK smiling at a lady teller

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do nothin' silly now. Cut to CLYDE standing near the door, training his guns on the entire bank.  A farmer stands a few feet away, some bills clutched in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That your money or the bank's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the floor, the bank guard in the corner takes advantage of CLYDE's distraction to go for his gun.  CLYD spots it and fires a shot that just knocks the bank guard hat off without harming him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the guard, who has practically frozen in fear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time I'll aim a little lower. They finish robbing the bank.  They start to exit.  Near door stands a guard with his hands raised.  He wears sun glasses of the period.  As they leave BUCK snatches the s glasses from the guard's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a good look at us!  We're the Barrow boys. EXT. BANK.  DAY. The gang runs wildly into the street where the car waits, motor running.  As they leap into car, BUCK throws the su glasses into BLANCHE's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy birthday. They zoom off.  Shots are heard.  BONNIE, BUCK and CLYDE begin firing at the bank guards who are pursuing them.  T guards fire back. Close-up.  BLANCHE sitting in the back seat with her fing stuck tightly in her ears, eyes shut, trying to overcome panic.  A funny image, but one that also awakens pity.  T next sequence is carried out in cross-cutting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street in front of the bank.  Police car pulls up and the excited crowd gestures in the direction of the depart gang.  The siren starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The siren heard now in the far distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to C.W. at the wheel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kick it in the pants, C.W.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got to make that state line!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (driving like a wild man, but adlibing loudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't get more'n this out of a Plymouth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang has left a legacy of celebrity behind.  We see t bank guard whose hat was shot off being interviewed by a reporter.  He is seated in a chair, his shirt open at the collar and a woman teller is fanning him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enjoying the limelight)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he saw me goin' for my gun. Clyde Barrow himself, I mean.  And suddenly I was starin' into the face of death!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tsk, tsk. A photographer steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just look this way, Mr. Hawkins. The bank guard hurriedly buttons up his collar and smiles the flashbulb goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still speeding along, the siren more distant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bank president and a policeman are posing for that classic picture where both stand flanking a bullet hole i the wall and point proudly at it.  The flashbulb goes off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men in police uniforms following BONNIE and CLYDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step on it, Randolph.  We gotta catch 'em 'fore they reach the state line!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FARMER is describing BONNIE and CLYDE to passersby who do on him as though he'd just had contact with a portion of true cross.  FARMER is aware of his position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde?...he looked like, well he looked real...clean...and Bonnie, she's too much a lady ever to be caught with a cigar in her mouth...I don't care what you heard before. I saw 'em right here, not twenty minutes ago... (gravely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and all's I can say is, they did right by me, and I'm bringin' me a mess of flowers to their funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car slows up perceptibly as CLYDE says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, relax.  We're in Oklahoma now. Slow down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn around.  Don't waste no more gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a young eager beaver type)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't we gone to catch 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, they're over the State line. That's out of our jurisdiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we get 'em anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't gone to risk my life in Oklahoma.  That's their problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the gang's car is seen traveling down a long, narrow country road surrounded by cornfields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get out, taking the various bags of money with them, and dump the lot on the hood.  There is not an impressive amount of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell.  That ain't much, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (commiseratingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Times is hard,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's get to it. He begins dealing and splitting the money out on the hood the car, as they gather around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Clyde Barrow. (lays down a bill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck Barrow... (lays down a bill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie Parker...C.W. (goes back to the first again and lays out another round)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde, Buck...Bonnie...C.W. Clyde, Clyde again...Buck...Bonnie...C.W. BUCK and BLANCHE stand watching.  BLANCHE looks fretful. She nudges BUCK and whispers to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUCK whispers something back to her.  Meanwhile, CLYDE's counting still goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie...C.S....Clyde...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very ill at east in this position he has been forced into)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um...eh...Clyde?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah? BUCK is clearly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Clyde...well...what about Blanche? Everyone reacts with stunned amazement at BLANCHE's nerve wanting to get her cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous)

dialogues.speaker: WHAT
dialogues.text: BLANCHE sees she has to rise to her own defense, and she rises to the occasion with spirit and verve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why not?  Say I earned my share!  Same as everybody.  I coulda got killed same as everybody, and I'm wanted by the law same as everybody.  Besides I coulda got snake bit sleepin' in them woods every night! (building it up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just a nervous wreck and that's the truth.  And I have to listen to sass from Miss Bonnie Parker all the time.  I deserve mine! Close.  BUCK.  Day--looking at CLYDE, his face full of we smiles and embarrassment at his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sigh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...okay...hold your horses, Blanche.  You'll get your share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BONNIE is livid but says nothing.  CLYDE, the leader has decided.  C.W. looks indignant, like a hog who's just bee given a bath.  CLYDE begins counting all over again in ne silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Married a preacher's daughter and she still thinks she's takin' the collection. Everyone now laughs, but BLANCHE.  CLYDE continues counti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Blanche)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't spend it all in one place now, hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be doin' right well to spend it at all. BONNIE turns and ambles away from the car.  After a momen CLYDE stops counting and moves after her.  He's prepared a fight, stands behind BONNIE's arched back trying to gau the degree of hostility there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Bonnie, I've said it and I guess I'll keep sayin' it before we're thru--Blanche is Buck's wife and Buck is family. He waits expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally, utterly without malice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --she's such a silly-Billy... BONNIE looks plaintively to CLYDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My family could use some of that money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them laws have been hangin' round your mamas house 'til all hours, Bonnie.  It's just too risky to go there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, where can we go?  We rob the damn banks, what else do we do? CLYDE cannot really answer.  Suddenly C.W. starts yelling

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: CLYDE flinches at the sound.  C.W. comes bounding over, a rude an assault on their sensibilities as he can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wincing as they are nose to nose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you, C.W.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ol' heap's gushin' oil!  We got to swipe us another set of wheels right away, or we won't get anywhere.  Look here. He reaches down under the pan of the car and scoops a goo handful of slick black oil which he holds before their fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? CLYDE nods slowly.  He looks back to BONNIE.  He sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A residential neighborhood on a suburban street.  A rathe well-to-do neighborhood.  The camera is up on a porch of white frame house, looking toward the street.  On the por sitting in the swing in the left f.g. are a MAN and a WOM She is about twenty-nine, he is about thirty-six.  He is sitting with his back to us, embracing the WOMAN.  They a spooning, making low, loving murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now...now, dear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm...sweet thing... We see in the distance two cars parked in front of the ho His and hers.  Suddenly we see another car drive up (BONN and CLYDE) and somebody gets out.  Then the whole gang ge out, ditches the one car and gets in one of the parked ca All the while the couple on the porch is busy spooning. car begins to roll slowly into the street.  The WOMAN not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, isn't that your car, Eugene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still nuzzling her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmmm...huh? (he looks, leaps from the swing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my car!  Hey! The MAN and WOMAN run down the front steps and front walk the second car.  They jump in and take off, giving chase. INT. CAR.  DAY. The WOMAN is driving (it's her car).  The MAN is furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tear 'em apart!  Those punks! Steal a man's car right out from under him!  Wait till I get my hands on those kids, Velma, I'll show 'em! They continue driving, furious, the man cursing and mutte We see through their windshield the other car way in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if they have guns, Eugene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing the possibility, he suddenly stops being mad and turns chicken)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd better get the police and let them handle this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn around and let's get back to town.  We'll go get the sheriff. They are by now on a narrow dirt road and the WOMAN has t execute a U-turn.  It takes her about seven cuts to turn car around in the narrow space.  They start back to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUCK looks out the rear window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stopped chasin' us.  They turned around. Close-up.  CLYDE grinning mischievously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take 'em. BUCK and C.W. laugh appreciatively at the reversal.  CLYD turns the car around.  He performs the U-turn in the same narrow space in one, swift, smooth, beautiful turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VELMA looks in the rear view mirror and sees that now she being chased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my Lord, they're comin' after us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a panic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step on it, Velma, step on it! Close-up.  Accelerator.  VELMA jams it down to the floor. The car speeds. EXT. ROAD.  THE CHASE.  DAY. BONNIE and CLYDE's car gaining on them, gaining on them, gaining on them and finally overtaking them, coming up an ahead, forcing them to the side of the road. Med. shot.  The MAN and WOMAN's car.  Terrified, they rol up their windows, lock their doors and huddle together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Barrow gang piles out of their car and walks over, having a merry time.  They surround the car and press the faces against the window, flattening their features, maki menacing gestures at the shaking pair inside.  We see thi from the point of view of the MAN and WOMAN inside the ca CLYDE pulls out a gun, makes as if to shoot, but he is kidding.  They all laugh uproariously, especially BUCK wh is delighted with CLYDE's prank.  All of this we see in pantomime from inside the trapped car. EXT. CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, get out!  Get out of there, I said. They come out, hands held high, shaking with fear.  They have practically turned to jelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ordering them into the other car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in here. INT. OTHER CAR.  DAY. They get in and the gang gets in.  Seven people are now jammed inside.  CLYDE drives, BONNIE next to him, C.W. ne to her.  In back, BLANCHE, then EUGENE with VELMA (of necessity) sitting on his lap, and then BUCK.  As will be seen, the reason the Barrows have kidnapped the couple is simply that they wanted company.  Living as they do, seei only each other day after day, they long for diversion an new faces.  So the atmosphere in the car will shortly cha to one of friendliness and jollity, and it will get progressively more so in the series of cuts which advance the time.  As the car starts up at the beginning, however the MAN and WOMAN are terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Eugene Grizzard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Velma Davis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just as friendly as he can be)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, howdy!  We're the Barrow gang. That there is Clyde drivin' and I'm Buck. The MAN and WOMAN almost faint from fear; clutch at each other.  The gang all laugh at this.  VELMA and EUGENE beg to realize that they are not going to get hurt and that t Barrows are friendly to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, don't be scared, folks.  It ain't like you was the law.  You're just folks like us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agreeing over-enthusiastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, that's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect you been readin' about us. The MAN and the WOMAN answer simultaneously with what the think is the right thing to say under the circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They glare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaningfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Velma, we have too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing at the contretemps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you two must be in love, I bet. EUGENE and VELMA blush, get shy for a second.  BONNIE smi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gleefully, clapping his hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when you gonna marry the girl, boy? Everyone chuckles heartily.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. LATER.
dialogues.text: --still driving, same positions, but some time has elapse The atmosphere is now completely convivial and the captiv are enjoying their new friends.  As the scene starts, BUC is finishing his joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then she drinks her milk down again, every drop.  And she looks over at her son and says, "Son, whatever you do, don't sell that cow!" The couple laughs with great amusement, but everyone else the car doesn't laugh--this is the tenth time they've hea the joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --getting on toward evening.  All are thoroughly relaxes chatting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Velma)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-three. A sudden look of surprise registers on EUGENE's face. INT. OF CAR.  NIGHT. It is now night.  Everyone inside the car is eating. Apparently they stopped somewhere along the way for food. In the crowded interior, it is like a party--food is bein passed back and forth, laughter and gaiety, increasing warmth between the couple and the Barrows.  The car has become a little society on wheels, dashing through the bl night down the highway.  Inside there is a small world of happiness and fun. BUCK is unpacking the food and passing sandwiches and dri around the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I ordered some French fries, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passing her some)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, here you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy on those French fries, Velma.  Ain't that right, Eugene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying his hamburger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't mine.  I ordered mine well done.  Who's got the other hamburger? Close-up.  C.W. who has already taken a bite of the other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is this supposed to be yours? He extends the bitten burger out to EUGENE. Full shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, forget it. CLYDE laughs at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chewing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haw!  I sure am havin' a good time! How 'bout you folks?  Ain't you glad we picked you up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, maybe y'all ought to join up with us. That idea strikes everyone as being very amusing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha!  Wouldn't they be surprised back home to hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  What would Martha and Bill say if they heard that? (she roars with laughter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lordy!  They'd throw a fit! (roars with laughter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as his laugh begins to fade)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an undertaker. Suddenly everyone freezes.  A shudder, as if the cold han of death had suddenly touched the occupants of the car. atmosphere changes to cold, deadly, fearful silence in exactly one second.  It is a premonition of death for the Barrows, and they react accordingly, BONNIE especially. Close-up.  BONNIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tautly, in a flat voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get them out of here. EXT. ROAD.  NIGHT. The car brakes to a sudden stop.  The rear down is opened the MAN and WOMAN flung out into the darkness.  The car drives off into the lonely night. From this point on, the audience should realize that deat is inevitable for the Barrow gang, that it follows them always, that it waits anywhere.  It is no longer a questi of whether death will come, but when it will. EXT. WOODS.  MORNING. Moving with CLYDE he tears through the brush, snagging hi clothes, calling BONNIE's name.  CLYDE's search is so desperate here that for a moment we might think he is fleeing from something rather than looking for something. In a moment he emerges onto the road.  The car, with C.W. driving, and BUCK and BLANCHE beside him, is patrolling slowly up ahead of him. CLYDE spots it and runs toward it.  Hold on this angle un he catches up with it and leaps onto the running board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving shot.  Car.  Morning.  CLYDE, now on the running board, his head poked into the car, his face apple red an sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathing heavily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...see anythin', Buck? BUCK is shocked at his brother's desperation, but makes n overt comment on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --not yet, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an edge of paranoia, as if the three of them might be withholding something from him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and nobody saw her leave, or heard anythin' (almost a threat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE gets the point.  For the very first time we see CLY the leader, helpless as he hangs onto the running board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lamely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, where do you think she could've gone?...Buck?...Buck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed and a little frightened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I don't know... CLYDE looks helplessly at his brother, then drops off the running board and continues on foot, running along, scann the fields--the car keeping up beside him as he runs and truck before both car and CLYDE. Angle on car through windshield.  Reaction shot.  Day.  B turning to BLANCHE, shrugging his shoulders, speechless. Reverse angle through the windshield.  Day--at CLYDE, who has suddenly seen something begins gesticulating wildly, almost--from car's POV, a little comically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There!  There!  There!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts running off into a cornfield. Another angle--picking up CLYDE as he kicks his way into cornfield, knees pumping high, knocking down the stalks. stops and picks up the stocking he had spotted, takes it moves on. Still another angle as CLYDE has picked up a freshly beat trail through the cornfield.  He picks up one of BONNIE's scarves, now.  As he runs on, he clears a knoll and BONNI her yellow hair unmistakable even at this distance, comes into view.  She's far off in the cornfield, stalking off, looking neither to right nor left, carrying a brown paper sack that has split, from which she has occasionally lost clothing.  CLYDE screams, "BONNIE." She apparently doesn' hear. Angle on cornfield.  Day.  As CLYDE gets closer.  BONNIE herself suddenly breaks into flight, the paper bag splitt completely, the remaining clothes spilling out.  There is real chase where they each try to get the advantage.  CLY is so exhausted from his run that he has real trouble cornering her as they maneuver up and down the rows of co Finally CLYDE catches up. Extreme close-up.  BONNIE & CLYDE.  Day.  As they tum into the stalks of corn, mowing them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone!  Leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding her, kissing her frantically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey...hey, hey, baby, hey, Bonnie, hey baby... (calming her down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hey, hey now...just where did you think you were goin'?... BONNIE doesn't answer. Up angle.  POV CLYDE.  As he's momentarily distracted by BUCK's laughter as he's in the cornfield picking up BONNI clothing.  CLYDE waves an impatient it's all-right-wave. turns back to BONNIE who he still holds tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still frantic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Huh.  Bonnie?  Where?  Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know!  You're hurting me, I was just scared is all...and my mama's been on my mind, and she's gettin' so old... BONNIE hesitates, beginning to feel a little foolish now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, don't ever leave without sayin' somethin'.  You really scared me, Bonnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I mean it, though.  I want to see my mama.  Please, Clyde. Two shot.  BONNIE and CLYDE.  Day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enormously relieved, kissing her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --of three or four cars parked on the side of a road in Texas.  A light rain is falling.  There are a lot of peop gathered around, but the sound is an indistinct mixture o talk, laughter, etc. There follows a quick montage of cuts which isolate speci moments in the family reunion, thereby implying the entir tone of the proceedings.  The sense of family pervades. Montage.  BONNIE and MOTHER.  BONNIE's mother, an old wom grabs her and hugs her and cries. Montage.  BONNIE, CLYDE, MAN.  A man, an uncle perhaps, stands with BONNIE and CLYDE, arms around them both, hugg them to his sides tightly. Montage.  BONNIE and sister.  BONNIE's sister hands them scrapbook of clippings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are, we been cuttin' and pastin' everything we could find about you in the papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE, BONNIE, BUCK and BLANCHE all look at the scrapbook We see a page of it, showing newspaper articles with the photographs the gang took back at the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey look, here's that one I took of you, Clyde.  That came out just fine! Montage.  BONNIE, CLYDE, MAN.  BONNIE and CLYDE are posin for a comic snapshot.  A silly looking male relative is posing, pointing a gun at them.  They have their hands in the air and are grinning broadly.  (The effect should be funny and simultaneously frightening.) Montage BUCK, SMALL BOY.  BUCK is sitting with a little four-year-old on his knee, bouncing him up and down and singing.  Both are having a fine time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Horsey! keep your tail up, keep yer tail up, keep yer tail up, Oh, Horsey! keep yer tail up, Why don't you make it rise. Montage--C.W.  A hand off camera thrusts a sandwich at C. He opens the bread to see what's inside it, then eats it. Montage--BONNIE & SISTER.  BONNIE sits stock-still wh sister gives her a permanent in the back seat of a car. sister pauses, setting down the curling iron.  She stroke BONNIE's yellow head with her hand, as though she were a wild animal that had paused long enough to be petted. BONNIE turns to see her sister's expression.  They embrac Montage--Family picnic--Favoring CLYDE, MOTHER & BONN CLYDE, in his best theatrical manner has been playing hos in the sand pile, perhaps using some sort of towel across the arm or around the middle.  The party is beginning to break up now as used paper plates and crumpled napkins ar blowing across the sand and the group is finishing up on Eskimo pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where y'all headed from here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (right back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, what y'all got in mind?  At this point we ain't headin' to anywhere, we're just runnin' from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE laughs, in fine spirits. Reaction--BONNIE.  She doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, down, Litte Tom!  We're goin' home.  Little Tom?  Mathew, fetch Little Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go yet, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mere, c'mere you little corn roller. Wide angle.  As Uncle sweeps up the laughing little Tom. Reaction--BONNIE.  BONNIE turns with increased urgency to her MOTHER, who, having been hefted to her feet by BONNIE sister, has turned to CLYDE, who gives her a big, boyish

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you know, Clyde, I read about y'all in the papers and I'm jes' scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Clyde)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar, make mama stay a while yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Bonnie, as does Mother, ebulliently, even joshing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Mrs. Parker, don't y'all believe what you read in the papers! That's the law talking there.  They want us to look big so's they'll look big when they catch us. He knows he's stumbled onto the wrong thing, but he bounc right along--it's his style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and they can't do that.  Why, I'm even better at runnin' than robbin' banks--aw shoot, if we done half the stuff they said we did, we'd be millionaires, wouldn't we, old sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he turns to Bonnie who continues to stare at her Mother)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I wouldn't risk Bonnie here just to make money, uncertain as times are.  Why one time I knowed of a job where we could of make $2000 easy, but I saw the law outside and I said to myself, why Bonnie could get hurt here.  So I just drove right on and let that money lay. He waits for a response, as does BONNIE.  BONNIE's MOTHER smiles, a little abstractedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Maybe you know the way with her, then.  I'm just an old woman and I don't know nothin... She trails off, looking nowhere in particular.  CLYDE tak her reaction to mean that he's overwhelming her with his confidence, and continues to pour it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be quittin' this just as soon as the hard times is over, Mother Parker, I can tell you that.  Why me and Bonnie were just talkin' the other day and we talked about when we'd settle down and get us a home, and Bonnie said, "I couldn't bear to live morn'n three miles from my precious mother." Now how'd you like that, Mother Parker? BONNIE's MOTHER has undergone a funny sort of transformat during CLYDE's speech--as if something had suddenly come into focus before the old woman's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't believe I would.  I surely don't. (to Bonnie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You try to live three miles from me and you won't live long, honey. (to Clyde)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd best keep runnin' and you know it, Clyde Barrow. (matter of fact)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hugs BONNIE who can barely respond.  We move in for a closeup of BONNIE as her various relatives, young and old come by to squeeze, kiss and hug her with a chirpy little chorus of Bye, Bonnie!  Bye, Bonnie, bye, bye, bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on the outside long enough to see the unusual structures: two little motel cabins connected by two identical garages, an entirely symmetrical structure. INT. PLATTE CITY MOTEL BEDROOM.  WITH BONNIE.  DAY. --as she tries, against heavy odds, to file and trim her nails in a corner of the room.  The odds are; CLYDE on a uke, b.g., BUCK, and BLANCHE--gathered around C.W. who si in the only stuffed chair in the room.  Their o.s. raucousness is clearly shattering to BONNIE who, at a key moment in the scene, ends up spearing her cuticle with a file, spurting a little board and a lot of temper. Other angle.  CLYDE--BUCK--BLANCHE--C.W.  Day.  A naked lightbulb (the lampshade has been removed) glares down on C.W.'s chest--where a pair of bluebirds have been tattooe with a rocco flourish.  BUCK and BLANCHE are vastly amuse rather BLANCHE takes delight in BUCK's delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have ya had it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like some docile animal submitting to inspection)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --just got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Blanche, who stares fascinated as one of C.W.'s pectoral muscles contracts and the wings flutter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touch it, honey!  Go on! BLANCHE squeals with amusement.  BUCK takes BLANCHE's han and places it on the bluebirds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (titillated with delight)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, Daddy!  No! Reaction BONNIE.  Day--as the file digs into her cuticle BLANCHE's squeal.  With barely controlled rage:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you all doin'? INT. MOTEL BEDROOM.  GROUP SHOT.  FAV. BONNIE.  DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insensitive to Bonnie's stare)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playin' with my tattoo, Bonnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why don't you all go play with it somewhere else? New angle.  Motel bedroom.  Day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's bothering her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sees something coming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, Blanche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who doesn't want to be victimized by Bonnie's temperament)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's bothering her, Clyde?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said go somewhere else! She picks up the first three objects she can find on the dresser and hurls them--an ashtray, a Gideon Bible, and a flower pot--at the little group.  The pot goes shattering into the wall.  Everyone ducks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straightening up, matter-of-fact)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie's hungry, C.W. I saw a chicken place a few miles back. Who all wants to go get some food? INT. MOTEL BEDROOM.  GROUP SHOT.  DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising from her chair, a little shaken at Bonnie's outburst)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure do.  I'm plenty tired of sittin' around here anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not making a move to get up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't drive, honeylove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go. CLYDE makes a face to BONNIE pretending there's something going on between C.W. and BLANCHE.  BONNIE tries to keep from being amused.  C.W. moves out with BLANCHE.  BUCK ri to go next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's everybody want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just five chicken dinners, and get somethin' for dessert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See if they got peach ice cream. (he grins and pats his stomach)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All finally exit, leaving BONNIE and CLYDE alone. EXT. CAR AND STREET.  DUSK. C.W. and BLANCHE go out.  We go with them.  They get in t car and drive off.  BUCK enters his cabin. INT. MOTEL BEDROOM.  BONNIE AND CLYDE.  DUSK. CLYDE reaches her, and for a moment both stare with fanat intensity at each other, BONNIE trying desperately to kee straight face.  They are nose to nose, unblinking.  CLYDE gives her a big raspberry, waggling his fingers in his ea like a kid.  She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate you all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate y'all, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: no, I really hate you. She turns away from him, wilts onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes brimming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, baby, I've got the blues so bad... CLYDE moves behind her, begins to massage her back.  Ther is something very delicate about the way he touches her; suggests CLYDE's sensitivity to her mood rather than any degree of physical intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie?...is it your mama, what your mama said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What mama?...she's just an old woman now...I have no mama... BONNIE rolls over on her back, stares up at CLYDE, tears splaying across her face from the move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so funny...I thought when we first went out, we were really goin' somewhere...but this is it-- we're just goin', huh? She has addressed this last directly to CLYDE, but there nothing rhetorical about it--it is a real question.  CLYD doesn't answer for a moment.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you care about where we're goin'? BONNIE clearly finds this hard to say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as long as you care about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quite simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why I love you, sugar. It's the first time he's said it to her, and BONNIE is overwhelmed.  She wraps her arms around CLYDE's middle, a snuggles into him, like a child.  Neither we nor CLYDE ca see BONNIE's face now, and her voice is muffled by his ch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --enough to die with me, baby?... 'cause I think that's where we're goin'...I surely do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE is both touched and amused by the plea.  He strokes her head lightly.  Really meaning it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --wherever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLANCHE, her tense and agitated self growing increasingly more so lately, lights a fresh cigarette off the butt of one she has been smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conversationally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure smokin' all the time lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quick to take offense, snaps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'. BLANCHE, sick of it all, drops her head in her hand with sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God... C.W. looks at her, finally decides to say something that occurs to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whyn't you go back home to your papa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it's been her dream)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, if I could!  If I could just do that one thing!  Oh, there's no tellin' why this all happened.  I was a preacher's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When church is your pa affiliated with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (much more interested in talking about herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baptist...oh, and he thought the world of Buck, my daddy did, even knowing that Buck was serving time in jail.  He forgave him for that 'cause he paid his debt to society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were Disciples of Christ. INT. FRIED CHICKEN CAFE. The camera remains stationary in this scene, in this posi A lunch counter sweeps down the center of the screen.  We are at one end of the counter.  In the f.g., a DEPUTY sit drinking coffee, absorbed in his cup.  In the b.g., at th other end of the counter, by the Exit door, BLANCHE and C are being handed their order by the counterman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, C.W., I ain't got my money. Give me some, will you? The DEPUTY turns his head and looks over there.  C.W. ope his jacket to reach in his pocket for money.  As he opens his coat, his gun is clearly seen tucked in his pants. Camera zooms in to tight close-up of gun. Close shot.  DEPUTY--his face tense.  Sound of door closi shut, as C.W. and BLANCHE leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to counterman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get Sheriff Smoot on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On C.W.'s moonlit chest and face, tattooed bluebirds heav and occasionally snoring in the night.  Behind him the ro is dimly lit by flickering candles that are placed out of sight on the floor.  The shapes in the room--the bed is gutted and only the box mattress remains--dresser, lamp shades, etc., are grotesque in the flickering light.  O.s sounds of BONNIE and CLYDE, BONNIE giggling and CLYDE whispering something we can't quite hear. Move across the room toward the gutted bed.  Move gigglin from the floor beneath the box mattress--for a moment it should appear as if something perversely sexual may be go on between BONNIE and CLYDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw Bonnie--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coaxing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon! CLYDE's arm wielding a Tommy gun, clears the bed.  With t muzzle, CLYDE knocks the swivel mirror on the dresser overhead, bringing BONNIE and CLYDE into view. Closer angle mirror--BONNIE and CLYDE.  Night.  BONNIE li stiff as a statue on the white mattress, impeccably dress for her funeral.  Candelabras made of empty beer bottles at her head and feet.  BONNIE's hands and face are powder and painted a waxen white.  She wears a garish silk bow i her hair which it, for this occasion, curled like a littl girl's. CLYDE sits up, beer bottle in one hand, Tommy gun in the other, derby hat cocked--and just a little unsure of the whole thing.  He takes a swig--BONNIE stops him, trying terribly hard not to change her position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lie down now, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done enough! Angle on mirror--BONNIE and CLYDE.  Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with patience, to a child)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to lie down...it's the only way we can tell what we'll look kike together. She giggles again, more than a little gassed herself.  CL clamps a big cigar between his teeth and abruptly lies do beside her.  CLYDE is both amused and annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring up at himself talking with cigar clenched between his teeth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatta you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it suddenly strikes her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the right tie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising, weaving a little)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't wear polka-dots on an occasion like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stripes.  Don't go away now. She weaves her way over to the dresser, takes a swig from bottle there herself, checks her makeup, and returns with the tie.  Holding against his chest to try it out she alm falls into him.  CLYDE steadies her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect. She tries to tie it for him, and clearly has trouble with the knot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, o.k.  If we're gonna do this, at least I can tie it myself.  Lie down before you fall down. INT. MOTEL BEDROOM--BONNIE AND CLYDE.  NIGHT. She does, with some play-acting, exaggerated obeisance to CLYDE's command--reaching up at the last moment like a zombie and snatching an artificial flower from BLANCHE's which still lies on the dresser.  CLYDE lies down now.  T look into the mirror again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grudgingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much. This tickles CLYDE despite himself and he laughs--BONNIE begins to sing to him--performing for both CLYDe and her image in the mirror--like some hoydenish vaudevillian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the course of the song she will rise and take CLYD with her who finally joins in when they tip-toe over and begin to serenade C.W. BONNIE & CLYDE (to the lugubrious strains of the Death March)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Did you ever think when a hearse went by, That somebody you or I may die? They'll wrap you up in a big white sheet and bury you down just about six feet, The worms crawl in, the worms crawl out, The worms play penuckle on your snout. Your eyes fall in, your teeth fall out, Your face turns green and the pus runs out. During this last they have been hovering over C.W.'s twitching face, like a couple of tipsy ghouls, whisper- singing into his ears.  C.W. finally blinks, doesn't even bother to look at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna die if I don't get some sleep.  Quit singing that. Reaction--BONNIE and CLYDE.  Night.  They smile, go back lie down.  Looking at their images:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, shut your eyes now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing along with her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One for the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two for the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three to get ready-- CLYDE & BONNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four to Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they approach four we should feel that somehow when th shut their eyes, they really will die.  They shut them on GO, and screen goes black. EXT. PLATTE CITY MOTEL.  NIGHT. Ranged across the lawn are six police cars, loaded with peace officers.  Four men come out and, guns drawn, walk cautiously over to the room on the right--BUCK and BLANCH INT. PLATTE CITY MOTEL.  BUCK'S CABIN.  NIGHT. There is a knock on the door.  They sit bolt upright in b Before BUCK can say anything, BLANCHE puts her hand over mouth to shut him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are on the other side. EXT. PLATTE CITY MOTEL.  NIGHT. The four lawmen, among them the DEPUTY from the cafe, edg their way across the lawn, past the first garage, past th second.  Before they reach the door of BONNIE and CLYDE's cabin, the window smashes and there are blasts of gunfire One cop is hit and falls, the others run back to the cars for cover.  BONNIE and C.W. are at the window, firing steadily. CLYDE--running into the garage to get the car.  They must escape.  All they can do is escape, and all they have is that one car in the closed garage. Outside.  Two of the lawmen fall to the ground, shot.  As the remaining two run back for cover, we see a blinding light rolling up in a space between the six cars.  It is armored truck, with mounted guns and and spotlight, advan toward the cabin. Inside the armored truck.  Two men in the seat.  Sounds o gunshots coming from everywhere, piercing light.  From inside the truck, we suddenly see the windshield shattere from bullets fired by BONNIE and C.W.  The driver is hit, and he slumps over the wheel.  His body hits the horn, wh starts blasting and continues throughout the battle.  The other man, quickly, ducks under the dashboard for protect Inside the garage.  CLYDE standing by the car.  He holds Browning Automatic.  The garage door is shaking from the impact of bullets, shattering.  His gun already firing (automatic clip) before he gets there.  CLYDE in a crouch runs to the garage door, flings it up, and runs back insi the car.  Now the door is open and he can get the car out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hand on the wheel, one hand shooting, he rolls the ca out onto the driveway.  The battle is raging from all sid EXT. STREET. The car stops.  CLYDE keeps shooting.  The door of the ca flies open and BONNIE and C.W. come charging out, guns blazing away.  C.W.  fires the Thompson sub-machine gun, BONNIE fires two pistols with automatic clips.  They run a crouch, tryingto get inside the car in front of their d They make it. Camera pans across the motel to the other door.  It opens BUCK and BLANCHE come out, holding a double bed mattress front of them for protection.  This makes their running awkward--the mattress is heavy.  BLANCHE carries the fron end, BUCK the back with one hand, the other firing his gu They get halfway to the car and then BUCK is hit, shot in the head.  He falls to the ground; BLANCHE and the mattre fall too since she has lost balance.  Both are under the mattress. CLYDE dashes out of the car and drags BUCK into the back seat.  BLANCHE follows, hysterical.  All guns on all side are still firing.  They fling themselves into the car and from a standing start, the car starts out at 60 mph down driveway.  One of the lawmen stands blocking the way with double-barrele rifle, but the car keeps coming, about to him down.  He jumps out of the way and fires at the side. The glass cracks and we see BLANCHE fling a hand to her face, which is bloody.  A piece of glass has lodged in he eye.  We hear her scream.  The horn is still blasting. INT. THE CAR SWERVING MADLY. CLYDE manages to keep it on the road.  They drive away. EXT. STREET. The police run back to their cars to give chase, calling to each other, unable to believe that the gang could poss have gotten away. INT. CAR.  NIGHT. as it is speeding down the highway.  Crazy, mad hillbilly music on the soundtrack.  Packed inside this car right no is more sheer human misery and horror than could be belie It is hell in there, hell and suffering and pain.  The ca is a complete mess.  C.W. is sobbing.  Everyone is hyster BLANCHE is shrieking with pain and concern for BUCK.  BUC is alternating between groaning and passing out completel BONNIE is yelling at everybody to shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only CLYDE, driving with both hands clenched on the wheel is silent.  The car is doing 90. EXT. SUBURBAN STREET.  NIGHT. The car from the outside, a half hour later.  They have eluded the police.  They are barreling down the road at t speed on a nice suburban street with proper homes.  It is the middle of the night, utter silence.  CLYDE stops the car, points to ca car in a driveway--it is a beautiful, shiny new and expensive automobile.  C.W. runs out, runs the driveway, peers inside, gets in, quietly backs it dow the driveway and pulls behind the gang's bullet-riddled getaway car.  Suddenly they both zoom off down the road together. INT. OF THE NEW CAR.  NIGHT. C.W. driving alone.  He is crying, mumbling, wiping his e and nose with one hand while he controls the wheel with t other. EXT. RING OF FIRS.  NIGHT. A wide field in the country.  This is Dexter, Iowa.  It i quiet.  We see, in a long shot that takes in everything, that this is a meadow surrounded by a ring of trees, a de forest that circles them.  The meadow, however, is large. The two cars drive into the middle of the field, headligh on.  They stop and the Barrow gang gets out.  They are in horrible shape--we can finally have a look at them.  Half dressed in their pajamas, bloody, dirty, in tatters.  Tho that can stagger out do so, others are carried.  A far sh of all this. Closer shot.  Moving closer to them, we see CLYDE and C.W lay BUCK down on the ground.  CLYDE begins to administer his wounds as best he can, mostly just wiping him off.  B is semi-conscious.  All are in a semi-daze.  BLANCHE fall to her knees, still clutching her eyes.  She is totally hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, please help us!  Dear Father in Heaven, get us out of this and Buck will never do another bad thing in his life! (she continues moaning, praying, sobbing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BONNIE walks over to the group, looking at BUCK, C.W. goe over to her.  Two shot--BONNIE and C.W.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't got a chance.  Half his head blown off. Camera pulls back to take in BLANCHE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My eyes! (she SCREAMS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I think I'm blind. (in the headlights)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...light hurts so bad... BONNIE walks over to the car and comes back with the sunglasses BUCK had given BLANCHE.  Moving her out of the glare, she helps BLANCHE put them on.  BONNIE now has an around BLANCHE, and BLANCHE shivers into BONNIE gracefull BONNIE is a little repelled by BLANCHE, but comforts her of genuine feeling for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clinging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, please get us to a doctor! Tell Clyde to get us to a doctor. We'll die here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helping with glasses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --here, hon'. BONNIE looks silently up to CLYDE.  CLYDE is looking dumb down at his mangled brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde, Clyde, please get us to a doctor. Though BLANCHE cannot see it, CLYDE has knelt down to the side of BUCK, taking BUCK's hand and with his other hand begun smoothing BUCK's hair back, away from the wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's your brother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently, knowing CLYDE will not and cannot answer BLANCHE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck can't be moved, now, hon'. BLANCHE's answer to this is hysterical sobbing, burying herself into BONNIE, mumbling half-coherent, muffled pray between the sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With BUCK and CLYDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde?...Clyde?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe I lost my shoes...maybe the dog hid 'em... (he lapses into unconsciousness again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE has begun to cry a little, continues to smooth back BUCK's hair with ritualistic regularity. Wide angle.  Night.  Camera pulls away, way back to wide shot of the entire field, showing the group in the center the darkness, lit by the headlights. Match dissolve into early dawn, camera still on the wide shot.  The field is lighter, though the trees still loom blackly around it.  The two cars, one almost a shattered wreck, the other bright and shiny and new, are parked in center.  The sky is light, but the trees cast a dark shad on the field.  The gang is just sitting around.  BLANCHE weeping next to BUCK, C.W. sitting on the running board o car, staring.  BONNIE standing and smoking.  CLYDE still with BUCK. All is quiet. EXT. WOODS.  DAY. From the edge of the woods, a man in a white shirt emerge from behind a tree.  The camera swings abruptly to get hi He calls out to the gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrender! It is a total surprise.  BONNIE, CLYDE and C.W. all grab their guns and fire several shots; they are not firing th big guns now, but the pistols.  The man lingers there for moment--he looks strange, white, luminous, like an apparition--and then he vanishes into the woods.  Silence long enough to make you think it was perhaps an illusion. Then there is a volley of gunfire--a noise so large as to almost an impossible sound--coming from the woods, all around, everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ring of little white puffs of smoke emerge from the woo from every tree a puff of smoke.  The camera pans in a circle.  Behind every tree is a man with a gun.
