There ar at least 150 people out there--peace officers, farmers wi hunting rifles, kids with squirrel guns, everyone who wan to come along and catch BONNIE and CLYDE.  Their number i so large because this time they want no possibility of th gang making what seemed by them supernatural escapes. From this point on, the sound of guns is unnaturally muff on the sound track.  We hardly hear them at all..it is li a dream. Without a word, all of the gang including the half-dead B making his final effort, scramble for the nearest car.  T run, throughout this battle, crouched, like animals--thei only thought, to get away, to escape.  To fight it out wo be ludicrous. From the moment the Barrows start in motion, there is shooting again from the edge of the woods.  We see them scrambling towards the car, in an extreme long shot, surrounded by the ring of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them inside.  CLYDE is at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Med. Long shot of the car moving.  The sound track goes t complete silence.  We see the car looking for an avenue o escape.  It veers towards a tree, a man steps out from behind the tree and fires, the car jerks and veers toward another tree, again a man steps out and fires and so on. The car performs its eccentric dance, all in utter silenc (no sound of the motor, nothing).  The film should have t feeling of slow motion, as the car swerves and loops alon the edge of the woods.  Not once do any of the Barrows fi back.  Another man steps out and aims. INT. CAR. Close-up.  CLYDE.  At the wheel-shot in the arm.  He grab his arm in pain, loses control of the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --out of control (still silent).  It smashes into a tree stump.  The picture stops, freezes for three beats.  We h the image of the moment of crash, with pieces of metal crumpling and flying into the air, suspended there by the stop-film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound partly up again, but never at its realistic volume. From inside the smashed car, we peer out the window acros the field and see the other car.  The thought strikes the audience at the same time it strikes the gang--they must to that car. Med. shot of the second car, sitting in the field, shinin in the sun.  The lawmen also realize what must be done--c off this escape.  Though BONNIE, CLYDE and the others are heading toward it, they suddenly train all their fire on car rather than the gang. The car fills the frame of the screen.  Bullets begin to it.  It starts to quiver under the impact.  For the next minute, we see the car die in front of our eyes.  We see beautiful machine fall to pieces--windows smash, tires to apart, body riddled.  The death of the car is as painful watch as the willful death of a human being.  The executi is paced deliberately to show the ritualistic tempo of th destruction. EXT. WOODS. The camera pulls back, way back and slightly above everyt to reveal the entire field.  On the left of the screen, BONNIE, CLYDE and C.W. are scrambling toward the edge of woods.  In the center BUCK and BLANCHE have taken cover behind a fallen log.  In the foreground, police begin to emerge from the woods.  The camera zooms rapidly in with them toward BUCK.  BLANCHE is screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't kill him!  Don't kill him! He's dying! BUCK is making a last feeble attempt.  The zoom continues past BUCK until it comes tight on his hand, a lawman's fo steps on his hand.  BUCK falls over.  He dies.  BLANCHE screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't die, Daddy.  Don't die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes berserk.  Five men, one hardly a teen-ager, grab her and hold her as she writhes and cries.  She is still wearing the sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have reached the edge of the woods.  Camera tracks w them as they run.  From all around come the sounds of the posse.  The three get in through the pines and come final to a deep stream.  They jump in and start across, running awkwardly in chest-deep water.  They are half way across when the police appear on the bank behind them, shooting. Close-up.  BONNIE.  Day--as she is struggling through the water.  A bullet hits her in the shoulder.  We must see t bullet clearly, we must see it go in her flesh so that we can feel it. Tight close-up of BONNIE's face as she screams.  It is th first time she has been hurt, and the scream is pure anim pain.  She cries out. EXT. STREAM AND CORNFIELD.  DAY. CLYDE, who has almost reached the other side, comes back gets her.  He drags her out of the water and into a cornf that starts growing on the opposite bank, C.W. helping. half-carries half-runs with her into the cornfield, as th field gets deeper and thicker. They stop for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panting, to Bonnie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw...saw a farm...up ahead...gotta get...a car... He starts to give over the wounded BONNIE to C.W.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, no... But CLYDE has not heard this last.  Working on pure adrenaline now, he struggles onward.  Camera tilts up slightly so we can see CLYDE as he essays his way toward farmhouse with a car in the distance.  After a few moment he disappears and we can hear only the cracking of the stalks as that sound too diminishes, Full shot.  Cornfield.  Day.  Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close.  C.W. and BONNIE.  Obviously some time later.  The both lie prostrate in the field, listening.  C.W. licks h lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh! They wait for another long moment, picking up only the tiniest sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as though it were the most logical thing in the world)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't die without Clyde.  I just can't. C.W. looks at her as if she's gone crazy.  After another moment the corn begins to tremble, and we hear the o.s. sound of an approaching car. With C.W. Day--tentatively lifting his head up to clear t corn stalks.  With him we see the car looming larger, bearing down on us, splitting the corn stalks.  The car finally comes to a stop a few feet in front of C.W.  BONN is on her feet, and CLYDE tumbles out of the car, practic before it's stopped, sweeping BONNIE into him.  For a mom both are in their knees a few feet from the running board the car, simply holding onto each other and not moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tugging at both of them frantically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon!  C'mon!  C'mon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have gotten away, but are still escaping.  C.W. is driving.  He is bare-chested.  CLYDE is beside him in fro his arm bleeding.  He falls in and out of consciousness. BONNIE is stretched out in back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her shoulder has been bandaged with C.W.'s shirt.  She is unconscious. INT. CAR.  LATE DAY. CLYDE comes half-awake and looks over at C.W.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head out, C.W.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (determinedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm goin' home to my daddy's farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.W. is driving down the road, hell for leather.  Nearing campsite, where there are about six Okie cars and pick-up trucks all loaded down, with a number of poor families seated around a campfire, cooking.  C.W. jams on the brak He gets out, looking totally exhausted. Reaction shot.  The faces of the Okies, looking at this sudden presence in their midst. Back to C.W.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about to drop)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can y'all spare me a little water? EXT. CAMPSITE.  FULL SHOT. One man, the leader of the group, dips a cup of water and approaches C.W. suspiciously.  He comes close enough to m C.W. reach out for the water, but withholds it from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Moss. This seems to be enough for the man, who gives him the wa As C.W. gulps it down, the man begins to circle the car, peering into it suspiciously.  Suddenly he starts and his eyes open wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in really hushed and reverent tones)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands there struck dumb, staring.  Those of the other who have heard him begin to come over.  Without a word th move quietly to the car and stare in. INT. CAR. BONNIE is out in the back seat; CLYDE is semi-conscious i the front seat.  He looks up through half-closed eyes. EXT. CAR. We see a woman pour a bowl of soup at the campfire and br it to C.W.  He accepts it. A man rolls a cigarette and lights it.  Then, very ginger as if afraid to really touch him, he reaches through the window and places it in CLYDE's lips.  It hangs there, CL unable to drag on it or remove it. Children peer through the back window. C.W. finishes his cup of soup.  He hands it and the cup o water back to a woman in the crowd. Quietly, moving together, the Okies step back.  C.W. walk to the driver's seat, gets in and shuts the door.  He sta up the car. The people push a bit closer for a last look.  CLYDE, una to do more, nods his head in a barely perceptive gesture way of saying "thank you" t ot the people.  The cigarette still dangling from his lips. The car moves off.  A YOUNG BOY pulls on his FATHER's shi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was they, Pa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Bonnie and Clyde, the bank robbers. A woman, nearby, smiles sweetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up outside the slightly ramshackle farm of MALCOLM MOSS, C.W.'s father, in Arcadia, Louisiana.  It sits, for a moment, in the dark.  Then C.W. honks the hor A few seconds pass, and the porch light comes on.  OLD MA MOSS comes out in his pajamas and peers into the darkness He is a fat man with gray hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there?  Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's C.W.  It's Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence! He runs down the steps, down the path to his son.  They greet each other, hugging for a second, looking each othe over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, it's good to see you, boy! He holds C.W. at arm's length to study him, and suddenly scowls at something he sees by the light of the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that on your chest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? (realizing what he means)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a tattoo...I'm in trouble. I'll tell you about it later.  My friends are hurt.  Help me get 'em in. MALCOLM goes to car and looks inside for a moment.  He wa back to C.W.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, what happened to them?  You in trouble, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  That's Clyde Barrow and Bonnie Parker. (reaction from Malcolm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We been shot.  Help me get 'em inside.  We gotta help 'em. They go to the car and drag the unconscious BONNIE out an begin carrying her up to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you get yourself marked up? A tattoo!  What in hell made you do a damn fool thing like that? They reach the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Pa, open the door. INT. SHERIFF'S OFFICE IN DEXTER.  DAY. Although the scene begins with a full-screen close-up of newspaper clipping with a photo, it is just a blurry-gray crowded scene of BLANCHE's capture.  Really impossible to make anybody out in the crowd.  Camera stays on photo as hear voice over of two men talking: a sheriff and his dep

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in the bunch that took 'er. See here?  Can you make me out? Here I am, see here, right behind Joe Boyd here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure enough, Billy, is that your head there? Camera pulls away, BILLY, a young deputy--cold, intense, humorless and square, carefully folds up the clipping and puts it in his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still can't figure how we let them other two get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an older, more genial type)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, seems as how nobody can get 'em somehow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sullen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...well, maybe this boy'll be the one to do it, this Hamer guy. Boy if he can't do it, Sheriff, ain't nobody but the whole U.S. Army can do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a new note of enthusiasm, gets up and walks to the window--turning to Billy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear he quit the Rangers on account of Texas got that woman governor.  Said he wouldn't work under no woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (respectfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's somethin' all right. Say, how many they say he shot anyway in his day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty-five they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a sea-cook! The door opens.  We see, full shot and then fast close-up FRANK HAMER.  It should be a complete shock to the audien this is the man kidnapped by the gang earlier and partial destroyed by BONNIE. HAMER is dressed in his Ranger outfit and hat, and again has that quality of sinister frenzy beneath his calm mann His attitude toward these lawmen is sheer condescension, friendly only out of convention, really superior and contemptuous of lesser workers in his field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with politeness arising from condescension)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, am I in the right place? Is this Sheriff Smoot? PETE and BILLY jump up from the chairs and walk over to HAMER, hands extended.  They are quite impressed by meeti in the flesh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mispronouncing his name)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Hammer.  I sure am pleased to meet you! (shakes his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coil of rope snaps into and through the paper, splittin it and revealing C.W.'s startled face.  CLYDE strides the porch angrily, snapping the rope. BONNIE and MALCOLM are seated along with C.W.  Through BONNIE has her arm supported by a sling and CLYDE has his shoulder bandagedm it is evident by CLYDE's heady indigna and BONNIE's attentiveness that both are well on the way recovery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still snapping rope)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLED?  What do they mean, fled? How in the nama God could I leave my brother to die when he was already dead when I left him? (livid)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was shot in too many pieces to pick off the ground!  Fled...what do they know, the papers or the police?... Suddenly he moves upon MALCOLM with enormous intent, as i by pounding the point home to the one relative stranger among them, he will justify it all.  MALCOLM momentarily flinches, then listens with intense deference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, while we were all lyin' around here, near dead, they had us holdin' up the Grand Prairie National Bank!  They hung that one on us just for luck, I guess. CLYDE shakes his head, still thinking this over.  Abruptl to BONNIE, with deadly seriousness:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what.  Soon's we get well, we're gonna take that bank! He breaks into a wicked grin, but then reels, catching himself on the porch railing.  He's obviously dizzy from exertion and anger.  BONNIE starts--then sees CLYDE is in control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remarking on his own dizziness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whooooooo, boy... (kneeling, to Bonnie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't know nothin'--do they, sugar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (assuring him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did all you could, hon'. Nobody coulda done more. C.W. has been studying hard on the torn paper, b.g.  Sudd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.  How come I'm always called the "Un-identified sus-spect?" Group shot.  Porch.  C.W. has trouble with this last phra BONNIE laughs.  This picks up CLYDE's spirits once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to C.W.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can just thank your lucky stars that's all you are.  So long's they don't have your last name, you're home safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toadying to Clyde, talking to Clarence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barrow's lookin' out for your interests, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...Hey, Pa, how you like havin' a coupla big deals stayin' with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (friendly as can be)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't that somethin' for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back in good mood, expansive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now, you been real nice to us, and I tell you what, let us pay you forty dollars for your hospitality, what do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting vehemently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no.  I don't want your money.  I'm just pleased to have your company.  Any friend of my boy's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Pa, let's have supper.  I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...okay, Clarence... (to Clyde)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome here, now you know that. INT. MOSS HOUSE. They go into the house.  Camera goes with them.  As soon they are out of earshot from BONNIE and CLYDE, MALCOLM tu on C.W. displaying an entirely different demeanor from th one he presented outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating tatto which flutters through C.W.'s open shirt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like trash, boy, marked up like that.  Cheap trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie says it looks good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie, what does she know.  She's just cheap trash herself.  Look what they do to you, and you don't even get your name in the paper-- just pictures put on your skin, by "Bonnie and Clyde"-- (more to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --why they're a coupla kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Daddy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just glad your ma ain't alive to see that thing. C.W. peeks at it, peering down at his chest, trying to br the bluebirds into focus, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see what's so bad about it... INT. HOSPITAL.  MED. SHOT OF THE ROOM. Seated in a soft chair, looking directly at us, is BLANCH BARROW.  Her eyes are completely covered with a white bandage.  She wears a hospital gown.  The room is white a bright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Med. shot.  HAMER in the doorway.  The nurse leaves.  He reaches in his pocket and pulls out a white handkerchief. He puts it over his mouth to disguise his voice, afraid s will remember it from the kidnap.  Quietly, almost on tiptoes, HAMER walks over to BLANCHE.  He gets inches awa from her face.  She still doesn't know he is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, but suddenly, his voice muffled by the handkerchief)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanche Barrow. She starts to her feet, then adjusts to his presence.  Sh is a bit panicked.  BLANCHE is now a defeated human being Her voice and manner bespeak great weariness, sorrow and still a touch of her old high-strung hysteria.  But most that is gone now, like everything else that was really vi in her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  What?  Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a monotone, a relentless questioner)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know your husband's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her voice flat and expressionless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the rest of 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the rest of 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't know.  I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get in with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting slow, but warming up to the subject, she begins to talk and talk for the sake of airing her troubles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to.  I didn't.  Buck said we was just goin' to visit, we wouldn't be doin' no robbin' and stealin', and then we went to Joplin and all of a sudden they started shootin'. (hysteria begins to creep into her voice as she relives it all)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we run off, God, I was scared. And then it was run all the time, and I wanted to go, I begged to go, but Clyde and Bonnie and C.W.--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seizing on it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.W.  C.W. who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.W. Moss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is pouring rain, middle of the afternoon, BONNIE and CLYDE are inside the car, sitting.  They have lived so mu in cars that they tend to still spend much of their time it rather than in a room.  There they are themselves. INT. CAR. BONNIE is in the back seat, her legs wrapped in a plaid blanket, writing poetry.  She looks like Elizabeth Barret Browning.  With one essential difference--her arm is in a sling and she is wearing bandages on the shoulder.  CLYDE in the front seat, reading a newspaper.  He is also parti bandaged.  On the dashboard is a box of ginger-snaps whic he eats while he reads.  They look domestic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want a ginger-snap, Bonnie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (busy, absorbed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, hum-umm. (then she realizes his nice gesture and smiles warmly at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But thanks anyway, Clyde. (she takes it all in, her situation, and looks content and cozy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's real nice here, just the two of us like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more interested in his paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. (something in the paper catches his interest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look here, honey, remember this? He holds up the paper; there is one of the photos from th motel, the one showing BONNIE smoking.  She looks up at i with mild interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, at the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying the picture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure don't resemble that no more. Close-up BONNIE.  She doesn't.  She has become totally fragile, the essence of herself.  She is writing on a pad CLYDE and BONNIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you writin' this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intensely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm writing a poem about us.  I'm writing our story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this appeals to his ego)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, are you?  Let's hear it.  If it's good, I'll mail it in to the Law and it'll be printed in all the papers again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let me finish this line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does so.  CLYDE munches a cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, here it is. Close-up.  BONNIE--as she reads intensely.  At the beginn of this montage, the camera remains on her face.  Behind we see the rain on the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Story of Bonnie and Clyde" You've heard the story of Jesse James-- Of how he lived and died: If you're still in need Of something to read Here's the story of Bonnie and Clyde. Now Bonnie and Clyde are the Barrow Gang I'm sure you all have read How they rob and steal And those who squeal Are usually found dying or dead. They call them cold-hearted killers; They say they are heartless and mean; But I say this with pride, That I once knew Clyde When he was honest and upright and clean. But the laws fooled around, Kept taking him down And locking him in a cell, Till he said to me, "I'll never be free So I'll meet a few of them in hell." The road was so dimly lighted; There were no highway signs to guide; But they made up their minds If all roads were blind, They wouldn't give up till they died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manuscript is lying on the police blotter.  HAMER pic it up and continues reading it.  He reads it in a halting way:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road gets dimmer and dimmer; Sometimes you can hardly see; But it's fight man to man, And do all you can, For they know they can never be free. From heartbreak some people have suffered; From weariness some people have died; But take it all in all, Our troubles are small, Till we get like Bonnie and Clyde. Close-up of a newspaper page.  The poem is printed all th way down the length of one column.  On the sound track, BONNIE's voice picks up the recitation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If a policeman is killed in Dallas, And they have no clue or guide; If they can't find a fiend, They just wipe their slate clean And hang it on Bonnie and Clyde. INT. CAR.  CLOSE-UP OF BONNIE.  DAY. The day is sunny and we see it through the car window.  S continues reading, but now she reads it directly from the newspaper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they try to act like citizens And rent them a nice little flat About the third night They're invited to fight By a sub-gun's rat-tat-tat. Some day they'll go down together; They'll bury them side by side; To few it'll be grief-- To the law a relief-- But it's death for Bonnie and Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BONNIE finishes the poem, as camera pulls back slightly t show that it is a different day, different clothes and th bandages are gone.  As she stops, she has an expectant an somewhat self-satisfied look. Close-up of CLYDE.  His eyes are wide, his mouth open, hi face shows surprise and delight and he is on the verge of giant laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in gleeful wonder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn!  That's me! A great laugh comes bursting from him.  Camera widens to take in BONNIE.  She is both startled and delighted by hi response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that poem! BONNIE giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; it is all starting to come out now--his realization that he has made it, that he is the stuff of legend, that he is an important figure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sub-gun's rat-tat-tat! (he begins to laugh loudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right in the paper! Close-up BONNIE.  Now laughing too, with a great feeling joy. Two shot.  BONNIE and CLYDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse James!  You hear 'bout old Jesse, now you goin' to hear 'bout Clyde! He puffs up with air and explodes like a steam valve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pshhhhhh! He grabs BONNIE and chuckles delightedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, Bonnie!  You musta been one hell of a waitress! Close-up.  BONNIE--laughing, her eyes filled with tears. CLYDE's hand wipes them away. Two shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head back and forth like a puppy, just so much glee in him that he can't hold it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooooh, that Clyde!  That's my boy, that Clyde! He looks at her with love and delight, hugs her tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie... (she hugs him back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Poem of Bonnie and Clyde!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing at the mistake, happy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Story of Bonnie and Clyde!  Oh, child, you really did tell that story! He pulls her to him, his face inches away from hers, abou to kiss her.  She is waiting, expecting... Suddenly, he l out one wild laugh almost into her mouth. He kisses her.  She kisses back.  They are chuckling, giggling.  They grow more ardent; they pull back and laug again.  They begin to make love. EXT. ARCADIA STREET.  ICE CREAM PARLOR.  DAY. Bright afternoon.  Camera across the street from an ice cream parlor.  Sign about it: "EVA'S HAND-PACKED ICE CREA A large plate glass window fronts the store, and through we can see the people inside seated at tables and booths. Prominent in our vision is MALCOLM MOSS, seated, facing camera.  He is seated across from another man, but we see him from the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MALCOLM is obviously doing a lot of talking and then some hard listening; gesticulating and looking disturbed.  Aft a bit of this, he rises from the table and begins walking toward the door.  The other man rises and turns.  We now that it is FRANK HAMER. MALCOLM and HAMER come out onto the sidewalk, squinting i the sunlight.  MALCOLM mimes some social pleasantries by of saying "goodbye," but HAMER's face shows no emotion of recognition of the gesture.  He turns and walks away, walking out of the frame. MALCOLM stands where he is, in front of the ice cream par By the expression on his face, we can see that he is rath disturbed by what he has heard and that he is still grapp with the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BONNIE and CLYDE.  They lie where they were with one difference--they are now wrapped in the blanket.  CLYDE's pants are wadded up and tangled with his shoes at the bas of the blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling, apparently quite pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn!...damn...damn! He casts a sidelong glance to BONNIE, wanting some sort o overt reaction from her.  She's just smiling slightly. CLYDE's underlying anxiety begins to surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, listen, Bonnie, how do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching him steadily, her slight smile growing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean you feel like you're s'posed to feel after you've uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't know what the fuck to say, desperately wants her approval)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's good, ain't it. Reason I ask is, I uh... Well, I figger it's a good idea to ask.  I mean how else do I tell if I did it the way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping him, with great warmth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.  You done just perfect. CLYDE looks at her for the first time, tremendously relie He can see she means it.  Now his buoyancy, utterly, unchained breaks through:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did, didn't I?  I mean I did, I really did.  I did it, I did, I mean this was my first time and it was just like rollin' off a log when it comes right down to it, it was easy, I mean I didn't even have to try... Lovingly, laughing, altogether overwhelmed with himself, CLYDE pulls BONNIE into him.  He kisses her, wants to mak love again, but then pulls back and keeps chattering at sixty miles a minute.  He's waited twenty-three years to talk about this, and he's got the perfect audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After dinner.  There are four empty plates, but only C.W. and MALCOLM in the kitchen.  C.W. is scraping the bottom a wilted "EVA'S HAND-PACKED ICE CREAM" carton.  MALCOLM studies his son's quiet intensity in this direction for a moment, then moves very close, whispers when he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, they expect you to go downtown with 'em tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out loud, licking his ice cream)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his own voice, infuriated by his son's obtuseness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie and Clyde!... (he slaps the carton out of C.W.'s hands; whispering again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie and Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I always go with them. MALCOLM thinks hard about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...better go then, you better go, better go... (forcing C.W. to sit at table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but when they get back in the car to come on home, don't get in with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just listen to your Pa fer once! Cain't you do that?  I'm yore Daddy, I'm your kin, not Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what should I tell 'em? "I can't get back in the car with you?" MALCOLM is ready to kill--his son's obtuseness and his fe of CLYDE is whipping him into a quiet frenzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squeezing C.W.'s arm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you tell them nothin', hear? (hesitates, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a deal and got you off with a coupla years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a piercing treble)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made a deal with who, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MALCOLM hauls off and whacks C.W. across the top of his h with the flat of his hand, then momentarily holds his han over C.W's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (we can see his own fear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the law.  Just don't get back in that car. (eyeball to eyeball)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And whatever you do, don't let onto them, hear? C.W. suddenly smiles, as if he knew something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expletive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew!... You think them laws are gonna catch Bonnie and Clyde in town? C.W. returns to the ice cream carton--MALCOLM lets him, figuring he better find out what he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think, Clarence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matter of fact)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't gonna catch 'em.  Don't matter whether I let on or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing along)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mebbe.  Just you be off'n the streets of that town when they go to get in their car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking directly at Malcolm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody catches Clyde.  Clyde's got a sense, don't you know that, Daddy? Nobody catches Clyde. MALCOLM knows better, but for just a moment he stares at son, fearing that maybe C.W., for all his limitations, ha sense about CLYDE's sense.  C.W. has finished with the carton and crumples it, licking the last remnants of crea off his fingers. INT. BEDROOM.  MOSS FARM.  NIGHT. BONNIE and CLYDE's bedroom, the middle of that night.  Bo are wide awake, lying on opposite sides of the double bed Both are staring into the night, disquiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie?  Bonnie, will you marry me? There is a silent gasp from BONNIE, a barely perceptible stiffening.  Then she talks in a voice falsely formal, st staring up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I do that, Clyde?  You know it's impossible.  We'd have to go to a Justice of the Peace and the Justice of the Peace is a lawman.  We couldn't even take out a license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a chuckle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey now, you sound like you been givin' it some thought on your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grim irony, her voice getting more and more emotional)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, I never gave it thought.  I haven't thought about it at least ten times a day, I haven't thought about it every minute of my life since I met you. (suddenly her voice cracks into tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flings herself violently across the bed and buries herself into CLYDE's chest, her knees drawn up, her head tucked down into him, her body shaking with sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit startled by this, attempting to hold her, awkwardly, and placate her.  He puts his arm around her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie...are you crying, honey? BONNIE nods yes and slowly gets control over her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her face still buried in CLYDE's chest, she whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde, why do you want to marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE thinks a minute and then grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in an attempt to be humorous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To make an honest woman out of you. BONNIE is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally, in a voice charged with anticipation and dream)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde...what would you do, what would you do it some miracle happened and we could walk out tomorrow morning and start all over again, clean, with no record, with nobody after us? CLYDE thinks about it a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I guess I'd do it all different.  First off, I wouldn't live in the same state where we pull our jobs.  We'd live in one state and stay clean there, and when we wanted to take a bank, we'd go to another state...and... Suddenly he realizes that he has said the worst thing he could have, that it was not the answer BONNIE wanted to h He looks down at her, his voice anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie? She is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bonnie? But she does not answer. EXT. ROADSIDE.  EARLY MORNING. We see MALCOLM jacking up the back wheel of his pickup tr which is parked on the side of the road in a wooded area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A street in Arcadia.  The car is parked.  BONNIE and CLYD walks toward the car carrying big bags of groceries and supplies and put them inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to C.W.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stopped off in that hardware store to get light bulbs for his daddy. CLYDE opens the door of the driver's seat and sits down. INT. CAR.  ARCADIA STREET.  DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, my feet are sweatin'. He takes off his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kidding around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You plannin' to drive with your shoes off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, why not? He reaches in his shirt pocket and takes out his sunglass As he goes to put them on, one of the lenses falls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! He puts them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna wear 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, drive with one eye shut. BONNIE gets in the car, rummages around in one of the bag and pulls out something wrapped in tissue paper.  She unwraps it and puts it up on the dashboard, displaying it It is a little porcelain shepherdess holding a crook in h hand, worth about thirty cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admiring it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that the prettiest thing, hon? Just look here, you can see every little fingernail on her hands. She shows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a pretty thing, honey. CLYDE turns on the radio and gets some hillbilly music. They are singing "Little Church in the Valley."  He beats time on the steering wheel, getting a little impatient. BONNIE puts her shepherdess away and begins looking in th grocery sack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got any peaches?  I sure could go for a peach right now. She burrows in the bag and comes out with a peach.  She takes a big bite.  The juice drips down the side of her mouth.  She looks beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he stops drumming his fingers, suddenly has an idea)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whyn't we do it tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow's Sunday, ain't it?  We could drive all night and be on that golf course tomorrow morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you feel up to it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, why not? (now feeling anxious and excited, he is impatient to move)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is that boy?  He's gone too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (humming to the radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be here. (holding the peach to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take a bite, hon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's takin' too long.  What if something happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more urgently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go take a look, see what's keepin' him. Not too delighted with the chore, BONNIE goes off.  We remain with CLYDE, getting anxious.  The music plays on. BONNIE comes back, hurriedly, now anxious herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't there. CLYDE jumps into action, slams his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, let's go. BONNIE gets in.  They drive off. INT. STORE.  CLOSE-UP C.W.  DAY. --hiding inside a store, peering out through a curtained window at them driving away.  His expression is disturbed his face half in shadow. EXT. ROAD.  DAY. BONNIE and CLYDE's car coming down the road.  Camera sees from CLYDE's P.O.V.  MALCOLM standing in the road, waving him down.  The pickup truck, its back jacked up, is parke beside him on a shoulder of the road. INT. CAR.  DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE reaches the spot, pulls off the road and stops the He gets out.  Camera pulls back.  CLYDE talks to the old man, BONNIE stays in the car.  Cut to a shut down the tre of the law, tense. Suddenly, a truck loaded with chickens comes riding down road from the opposite direction.  HAMER sees it from a l way away and realizes that he cannot afford to let anythi pass between him and his quarry.  He decides the time is He leaps up from the trench and yells at CLYDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barrow! The OLD MAN dives under his truck to hide.  The shooting starts. We see the chicken truck.  Two men in the front seat.  Th see ahead of them an incredible shooting match and, in terror, they jam on the brakes and leap out of the truck. They run as fast as they can into the meadow, away from t trouble. The gun fight takes just seconds during which law fires eight-seven shots at BONNIE and CLYDE, giving them absolu no chance.  The sound is rapid, deafening. At no point in the gun fight do we see BONNIE and CLYDE i motion.  We see, instead, two still photographs cut into sequence: one of Clyde, half out of the car, taking caref dead aim with his gun, just as he did in the teaching sce one of BONNIE, in terror, a pack of cigarettes in her han clutched tight, looking as fragile and beautiful as she c be. The noise stops at once.  Utter silence.  It has been a massacre.  BONNIE and CLYDE never had a chance to return gunfire.  We see the car, a complete shambles.  We never BONNIE and CLYDE dead, though for a moment we discern the bodies slumped in the car. The camera pulls above the car until it is on a level wit the opposite side of the road.  Then, slowly, the six law stand up in the trench.  On the faces of the five deputie horror and shock at what they have just done.  HAMER, however, registers no emotion.  His face is a blank.  He lights a cigarette.  Slowly, slowly, the five men begin t edge closer to the car to see the result.  Music, the wil country breakdown music, begins on the sound track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before they reach the car, the camera swings away from th past them, and zooms out and above into the meadow where two truck drivers are standing--tiny, distant figures. The truck drivers begin to walk toward the camera, coming back to the road to see what happened.  They get closer a closer to the camera until they have reached a middle distance and, as they continue to walk at us, it is--
